DEBATE.TITLE: ENVIRONMENT PROTECTION (ALLIGATOR RIVERS REGION) AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.

TALKER.NAME: Mr LINDSAY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Office of the Supervising Scientist, which includes the Alligator Rivers Region Research Institute, was established by the Commonwealth in 1978, following the Fox inquiry into uranium mining. The purpose of the office is to provide assurance to the Australian people that the environment in the Alligator Rivers region of the Northern Territory is not being adversely affected by uranium mining. The Alligator Rivers Region Research Institute has now carried out research on the impact of mining on the environment in the region for 15 years and uranium mining operations have been under way for 13 years. In this time, much background data has been accumulated and the operation of the Ranger mine has been relatively trouble free.

PARA.TAB: Given the continuing public sensitivity to uranium mining issues, the need to ensure satisfactory restoration of mine sites, the special significance of the Kakadu region and the Commonwealth's undertakings to the Northern Land Council and traditional Aboriginal owners, the government believes that a continuing Commonwealth role is essential. Nonetheless, after 15 years, there is room for adjustment without jeopardising environmental protection.

The government has decided to streamline and refocus Commonwealth arrangements. The decision was made following discussions between senior officers from Commonwealth departments, the Northern Territory government, the Northern Land Council and representatives of industry. I stress that following these changes there will be no diminution of environmental protection in the region. This is of paramount importance to the government.

Regulation of mining operations will continue to be with the Northern Territory government and working arrangements are to be improved following consultations with the Northern Territory government. There will be no lessening of the Commonwealth's commitment to ensuring environment protection in the region. The Office of the Supervising Scientist will continue to play a key role in supervising and assessing any impact of uranium mining activities in the region. The essence of the changes is:

SPEECH.PARA: .incorporation of the Office of the Supervising Scientist into the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency, thereby reducing administrative duplication and achieving economies of scale,
.refined mechanisms for consulting key stakeholders,
.enabling the minister to seek advice from the Supervising Scientist on environmental matters outside the Alligator Rivers region,
.allowing the Alligator Rivers Region Research Institute to undertake research on matters outside the region on a commercial basis; and
.establishment of an independent review of the research now needed to meet the Commonwealth's environment protection objectives in the region.

PARA.TAB: An independent consultancy to review the nature and priorities for research needed at this stage of uranium mining operations to provide a basis for maintaining a satisfactory level of environmental protection in the region is being arranged. In recognition of the importance of continued protection of the environment to the traditional owners in the Alligator Rivers region, the views of the Northern Land Council, as well as of other key stakeholders, will be taken into account by the independent review.

Implementation of some of these changes requires amendment of the Environment Protection (Alligator Rivers Region) Act and this is the purpose of the bill before us. The government has been working for some time towards strengthening its environmental management capabilities by consolidating various related organisational components. With this in mind, in 1992 the Supervising Scientist's head office was moved from Sydney to be co-located with the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency in Canberra. Complete incorporation of the office into the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency will lead to direct and indirect savings in the order of $650,000 per annum from 1994-95 onwards.

Because of the integration of the office into the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency, there will be no further need for the Supervising Scientist to have the powers of a departmental secretary under the Public Service Act 1922 and the relevant section is repealed by this bill. The Supervising Scientist for the Alligator Rivers Region will continue to be a statutory position with similar duties, powers and functions, but will now be an office in the Commonwealth Public Service and subject to the provisions of the Public Service Act in relation to remuneration and other conditions of service. The Supervising Scientist will continue to manage the Alligator Rivers Region Research Institute.

There are considerable gains to be had by setting the operations of the Office of the Supervising Scientist in a broader context and making the expertise of the organisation more available to others. Accordingly, it is proposed to amend the act to enable the minister to draw on the considerable knowledge in the Office of the Supervising Scientist to advise the government on environmental matters outside the Alligator Rivers region. I stress that it is not the purpose of this proposal to promote uranium mining development, either in Australia or overseas, but to enhance the quality and scope of specialist environmental advice available to the government.

While the Alligator Rivers Region Research Institute will continue to provide the research basis in relation to the impacts of uranium mining in the region, it will also be empowered to undertake scientific research on environmental matters outside the region on a fee-for-service basis. By undertaking contract research, the institute could earn up to 30 per cent of the Commonwealth contribution to its research program. Thus the institute will be able to contribute more efficiently to the national research effort by making its considerable expertise available to others, while at the same time strengthening its own capacity for research.

The bill will also establish improved arrangements for consulting with key stakeholders and scientific and technical experts. The Coordinating Committee for the Alligator Rivers Region will be replaced by two linked committees, the advisory committee and the technical committee.

The advisory committee will comprise the minister's appointees drawn from key stakeholders, including Aboriginal and environment groups, and an independent chair. It will provide a formal forum for policy consultation on matters relating to the effects on the environment in the Alligator Rivers region of uranium mining in the region, as well as commenting on, but not changing, recommendations to the minister from the technical committee.

The technical committee will advise the minister on the continuing nature and extent of research necessary to protect and restore the environment in the Alligator Rivers region and on the most appropriate organisations, including the research institute, to carry out the recommended research. The technical committee will have expert representation from the research institute, Northern Territory authorities, the Australian Nature Conservation Agency, the Northern Land Council and the mining companies. The chairperson and members will be selected by the minister. The government believes these new consultative arrangements will more effectively meet the needs of the Commonwealth and key stakeholders by more specifically focusing on policy and technical aspects.

In summary, the bill before the House will provide for a more up-to-date, focused and integrated approach to protecting the environment of the Alligator Rivers region. It will also achieve cost savings in delivering this important service to the people of the region, the mining industry and all Australians. I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —In 1997 the Commonwealth allowed uranium mining to take place in the Alligator Rivers region. This followed the Fox commission's report which recommended such action. The Fox report also recommended the establishment of the Office of the Supervising Scientist in 1978 to research the effect of uranium mining on the Alligator Rivers region in the Northern Territory. Since 1980 Energy Resources of Australia has been operating the uranium mine at Ranger.

PARA.TAB: There are five main points to this bill, as the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development (Mr Lindsay), who is at the table, has indicated. The first is that the Office of the Supervising Scientist, which has been a separate organisation, will be subsumed under the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories, specifically into the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency. In doing so, it maintains its statutory functions but the Supervising Scientist will no longer have the powers of a departmental secretary.

The bill further widens the Supervising Scientist's power to give advice to the minister where he or she requests it on matters affecting areas outside the Alligator Rivers region. Probably one of the most important changes, and also the most controversial, is replacing the coordinating committee with two committees—the advisory committee, which was, I think, initially to be called the consultative committee, and the technical committee. I will say more on that later.

Finally, the bill allows the OSS to undertake contract research outside the region. There has been some suggestion that this will interfere with the private enterprise of other organisations in the region. However, the short inquiries that I have made would suggest that, rather than limiting work for the private companies in the area, this will actually expand the amount of work available to them. None of them at present really specialises in the type of work that the Office of the Supervising Scientist does, and the Office of the Supervising Scientist does contract out to private organisations. From that point of view there is no concern on this side of the House at present.

There has been consultation with the Northern Territory government on this bill. It has said that it is still not happy with the role given to the Office of the Supervising Scientist. It feels OSS is too big, has too many staff, and is much bigger than the Fox inquiry ever envisaged. I suspect that Energy Resources of Australia would share that view.

The Northern Territory does point out that the uranium mining is also subject to the Department of Mines and Energy of the Northern Territory. There is an annual report and two six-monthly reports by the OSS. That was the territory's complaint about the legislation, although generally there is no particular opposition.

Prior to the introduction of this bill into the Senate I consulted with the Australian Democrats to see whether they had any amendments that they would like to put up at that time. They assured me that they were very happy with the bill and they had no problems with it. Subsequently, immediately prior to the bill's introduction in the Senate, the Democrats came up with six amendments, four of which have been incorporated into this bill. Generally, we agreed with the government's attitude in supporting four of the six Democrats' amendments and rejecting two. Consequently, included in this bill, the advisory committee has replaced the consultative committee.

There is concern about the duplication, with the one committee having been broken into two, and what this will mean for the technical committee. The Democrats, on behalf of the environment agencies, wanted an environmental representative on the technical committee. It was deemed that that environmental representative would not be appropriate, although it was deemed appropriate to bring in somebody from the Northern Land Council because it was felt that the Aborigines had a definite interest in that whereas the representatives of the environment group do not.

As the parliamentary secretary is no doubt aware, I believe there was considerable conflict between the environmental representative and the ERA representative on the OSS committee. Everyone was opposed to taking this into the technical committee, and it was felt that the function that the environmental representative was meant to perform would be performed equally well or better if the role were through the consultative committee.

I have no concerns as long as the advisory committee does its job. The right decision was made to appoint a member of the environmental committee to the advisory committee, and the opposition will have no concerns with the bill as long as that committee is taken seriously and its advice adopted by the technical committee.

In other amendments, the Democrats wanted to broaden the functions of the consultative committee. We agreed with the government that that was not appropriate because it duplicated the position on the technical committee. We agreed on the formalisation in legislation of the appointment by the minister of a representative from the environment groups and to the words `To protect and restore the environment of the Alligator Rivers region', to maintain a satisfactory level of environment protection.

Having covered the bill, I would like to briefly comment on the government's attitude to mining in the Alligator Rivers region. I find it enormously peculiar that this government can say that it is moral to mine in three places within Australia but that, immediately one opens four mines, it becomes immoral. I would have thought it was either moral or immoral and that whether one had three or four mines hardly affected the morality of the issue. However, the opposition will support the bill and the amendments made to it in the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Environment Protection (Alligator Rivers Region) Amendment Bill represents a restructuring effort of sorts by the federal government of the environmental research and monitoring agency, the Office of the Supervising Scientist, or the OSS as it is commonly known. Essentially, the bill provides for the integration of the OSS within a newly formed Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency, CEPA. It also reorganises the OSS committee structure, splitting the old consultative committee into two separate committees.

PARA.TAB: On the surface, the bill seems to be an effort by the government to bring some order to the large number of scientific, monitoring and regulatory related agencies which have popped up over the years. The OSS is but one of these. There are a profusion of others, and I could see that some closer organisation of these might prove, in some circumstances, to provide a higher level of efficiency and less of a burden on the industries they monitor.

More particularly, there has been an accumulation of evidence since the late 1980s, since the so-called Taylor review of 1989 commissioned by the then Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, that the structure, function and distribution of expertise within the OSS should be critically reviewed. The most recent of these was the ASTEC report from May of this year entitled Research and technology in tropical Australia.

The loose, uncoordinated relationships of the OSS with the Northern Territory government and the Commonwealth's own Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation, ANSTO, the dispersal of staff between Bondi and the Northern Territory, the poorly defined functional role of the OSS which has given rise to unnecessary tension between regulatory and research roles, and the peculiar and inefficient funding base for the OSS have all served to compromise its effectiveness. I am largely unconvinced that the bill provides any real improvement on all of this at all. The mechanical aspects of the bill give us precious few grounds for believing anything of consequence will come from its enactment. All we have is a few hopeful, if not heroic, phrases from the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly).

I note the exercise provides for cost savings for the government of around $600,000 from the 1994-95 financial year onwards. But there is absolutely nothing in the bill or in the second reading speech of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development (Mr Lindsay) which gives a clue as to how the reorganisation is to take place, how the new organisational structures will cooperate or the implication of the changes for other current practices affecting the operation of the OSS.
To say that this is a shoddy bill is an understatement. The bill has no detail at all and the amended version, as agreed to in the Senate, makes the situation none the clearer.

Honourable members would know that the Office of the Supervising Scientist has responsibility for conducting research into the environmental standards of the Alligator Rivers region, and especially so with regard to the possible effects of uranium mining activities in that region.

The focus of uranium mining in the region is the Ranger deposit located just to the east of the township of Jabiru in a project area some 80 square kilometres in size which, despite some popular misconceptions, is not part of the Kakadu National Park. Ranger is run by Energy Resources of Australia, ERA, and has been up and running for 12 or 13 years now. It has pumped some $5 billion into the national economy over the past 10 years, and has developed some of the highest environmental standards in the world.

Therefore it came as no surprise to me that Ranger Mining has won the prestigious Australian Minerals and Energy Environmental Foundation award for environmental excellence. This was an achievement which should not have gone unnoticed in this parliament as it demonstrated that an industry can work in coexistence with the surrounding natural environment and that Australia's mining operations can embrace the principle of sustainable development in a practical way while others sit around all day talking about it.

Ranger is a mine which off its own bat supplies about 10 per cent of the world's uranium demand, but does so whilst pursuing world best environmental practices. I think it was no doubt in recognition of this fact that the Minister for Resources (Mr Lee), in response to recent parliamentary questions I put to him, answered in the manner he did regarding whether he was ever aware of any environmental damage of consequence arising from uranium mining operations. It was a simple question: `Do you know of any significant environmental damage following uranium mining operations?'. He said he had never been made aware of any significant events whatsoever.

There we have it: a mining industry in a sensitive wetlands area performing strongly but acting in regard to the best environmental standards. I would say that is fairly typical of the mining sector these days. Companies like Hamersley Iron have picked up awards as well for their research work on flora and fauna habitats at Marandoo, so it should not come as a surprise to honourable members to find that the recent IBIS business information study found that Australian miners were amongst the best in the world, not just when it came to production efficiencies but also in respect of environmental issues.

Irrespective of this, we do have an environmental agency in the form of the OSS overlooking the activities of Ranger. The coalition has no problems with the idea of providing for a suitably strong scientific research effort in areas such as the Alligator Rivers region. But where we do have problems is with the policy and organisation framework of such bodies as the OSS and its exposure to political pressures and special interests.

TALK.START.PARA: —And with the three mines policy—period.
—And, as the Leader of the National Party interjects, we also have a very serious problem with the government's restrictive three-mine or two-mine policy in practical terms.

PARA.TAB: Let me return to the bill. I would like to pose some queries which the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories or the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mr Snowdon) will no doubt like to clear up in response to this legislation in the House—that is, if she has kept notes of the debate in the House following the recent debacle in her administration of the sporting and cultural grants.

Mr Speaker, do not let me be sidetracked. The point is I would like the minister or the parliamentary secretary to respond to a number of specific queries I have in regard to the bill before the House. We have the creation, out of the old consultative committee of the OSS, of two new committees, one an advisory committee and the other a technical committee. We have had pressure from the Australian Democrats to do all manner of things in regard to the composition of these committees. It wants to pop the odd green lobbyist on a committee here or there. It would be a disastrous step, I would have thought, to politicise an organisation, the very professional credibility of which rests on its scientific objectivity and remoteness from the political world.

This is an important issue and I cannot emphasise enough the need to keep the research program conducted in the Alligator Rivers region squeaky clean of any political agenda. The minister will need to watch this like a hawk and ensure that the composition and the interrelationships between the two committees have one objective, and one objective only: the pursuit of the higher standard of environmental science. The minister must make sure that the advisory committee does not become a forum for every interest group with an axe to grind against the uranium industry. The advisory committee must be a responsible group of professionals and not a political arm of some politicised special interest group.

Having said this, I would be interested to hear the minister's detailed explanation, in her summing up, as to how the dual committee structure is to be established out of the existing consultative committee. How, in specific terms, will this add to the efficiency of the current research effort? Or are we really just doing a variation on a theme—substituting one cumbersome organisational structure for another, with the simple motive that one is a bit cheaper to run than the other? For example, who decides the research agenda the new body will pursue? Is it to be determined by the technical committee or the advisory committee? If there is some cooperative arrangement between the two committees, what policy process will prevail in this regard?

More importantly, it is vital that the technical committee hold sway in matters such as the design and objectives of the relevant research projects. If a so-called representative advisory committee grabs the driver's seat when it comes to the focus of the research program, then we will see all faith in the Office of the Supervising Scientist evaporate. It will be embroiled in controversy and it will lose the confidence of the industry.

This last point—the confidence of the industry—is not to be sneered at. It is a prerequisite to one of the further objectives that the government is trying to achieve through this bill. That objective is for the OSS, in its new form, to embark upon a fee for service program—that is, like other research agencies, the restructured OSS must gear itself to meet increasingly larger proportions of its annual budget by way of earnings from the provision of relevant services from industry.

If the OSS is to achieve this objective, then it must be able to market itself and its technical skills to industry. If there is any hint or evidence whatsoever that the work of the technical committee is being driven by any political agenda, which may surface in the advisory committee, or that the research program is not being effectively targeted or focused, then that objective will be killed stone dead on the spot. I give this as a serious warning to the minister. I trust, like the industry, we will see good science prevail. This is doubly important, as neither the bill nor the minister's second reading speech gives any indication that the OSS has embarked on the construction of a business plan of any sort which will create a more industry relevant service arm of the OSS.

At the moment, I would have to say that the OSS could not sell a newspaper to the industry—let alone an industry relevant and commercially priced service. That is not a reflection on the quality of scientific expertise in the OSS; it is just a reflection on the distance that the organisation has to go before it develops programs which are of proprietary benefit and commercial value to industry. It took distinguished bodies, such as the CSIRO, a huge effort to reorientate their programs to an industry focus. Efforts like that are not switched on and off; they require shifts in culture and behaviour, which demand very sophisticated and sometimes tough-minded management decisions.

The OSS has a long way to go. It has no defined business plan, a questionable organisational structure, and no proven track record in industry related service division. If the minister thinks that she can simply say to this House and to the OSS, `Go out there and earn your keep'—but at the same time structures the OSS so that it is incapable of responding effectively to industry—then for all intents and purposes the whole exercise is a waste of time and effort. Again, if the dual committee structure does not give primacy for research focus, design implementation and evaluation to the technical committee, then there will be no purpose and nothing to be gained in pursuing the restructuring to start off with.

I also make the point that the bill and the minister's second reading speech do not give much by way of detail as to the fate of the existing uranium oxide export levy which funds most of the OSS annual budget—from memory, I think the levy raises some $7 million from Ranger per year. What the bill does not tell us is that, if the industry is now expected to pay for services from the OSS, is it also to continue to subsidise the organisation through its compulsory multi-million dollar levy? That is a simple question; I would be delighted if the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development, who is at the table, could give us an answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was that question again?

—Ranger must fund the OSS through a compulsory levy—some $7 million per year. Now that it must pay a fee for service from the OSS, will the government keep the levy in place? If it does, Ranger will be funding the organisation by way of a levy, plus paying for its services—talk about double dipping!

PARA.TAB: I know that the government has this matter under review, but the bill itself outlines no procedures nor any timetable for facilitating the transition from the levy to the external earnings. It would have been a more prudent policy if the crucial funding mechanism could have been presented in detail as part of the bill. Instead, we have a bill that is a hollow shell which anticipates undefined future changes in funding and does not even elaborate on how the organisational structure it creates will work.

Funnily enough, I am not surprised by all of this. The industry has seen the government move in this way before. Take, for example, the case of the Australian Geological Science Organisation, AGSO. The government has claimed it is reorientating AGSO to make it industry relevant. It claims it is putting AGSO onto external earnings requirements in line with other research agencies—perhaps others such as the OSS. But the reality of the whole exercise is totally different from the rhetoric.

I happen to think there is a fair swag of good science done in AGSO. Many of the research staff there are pretty well at the top end of the market as well. But government policies will kill AGSO, and the government and the Minister for Resources should recognise that fact. The organisation has had a fee for service requirement imposed upon it. Like the OSS, AGSO has no business plan in place.

Moreover, the so-called fee for service, or external earnings requirement, is so structured that it is a destructive mechanism for AGSO which is serving only to drive industry away from its doors, poisoning relations with potential client groups. It has not opened up the organisation to increased industry interaction.

Furthermore, government policy has breached an important policy principle in respect of the role of government in regard to baseline or fundamental research funding. Essentially, AGSO's so-called external earnings program is no more than a compulsory tax on industry. The petroleum exploration industry is being levied fees on its exploration permits to the amount of $10 million annually to pay for AGSO's continental margins project—a project designed to yield fundamental baseline data about frontier geological regions.

This is not commercially driven research, and the Department of Finance knows that is the case—it said so in its submission to the Richards review of AGSO last year. The continental margins project does not yield proprietary information—that is, data of commercial worth to industry. It is pre-competitive research at best. As such, I would have thought, if it were rightly the type of research that is of sufficient public benefit to be pursued in the first place, it should be funded from the public purse or through efficiencies or priority spending in the organisation itself and from appropriations. But, no, the government has dumped this policy principle and said, `We'll fund it through a compulsory tax on industry'. If I were the CSIRO I would be very interested in this trend.

The government is backing out of any commitment to support an appropriate level of support for fundamental research. This is a worrying initiative by the government, and shows that it is driven by short-term budgetary needs rather than any stable set of policy principles, something so crucial to the conduct of the nation's fundamental research effort. Even more disturbing, the compulsory tax on the petroleum industry will only serve to divorce AGSO from industry. This is not a user pays principle at work because no-one is using anything. This is not a fee for service as no service is being provided. And it is not a conventional external earnings mechanism. It is simply a compulsory tax, and it means nothing in respect of the capacity of AGSO to gear its programs to industry and actually earn income from the provision of relevant services and consultancies.

As I said, the only outcome of the initiative is that industry is about to walk away from AGSO. It will take years to heal the rift that is developing because of the misdirected push by the Minister for Resources to effect some savings from AGSO's not inconsiderable budget. I feel genuinely sorry that AGSO's staff and morale will suffer as a result of this poorly designed and ineffective exercise.

The responsible minister—the Minister for Resources—has had advice on this issue. He knows the implications. He knows it is a wrong-headed and destructive policy setting. Yet he persists, against the interests of the petroleum industry and against the interests of an important section of the national research effort. So those honourable members with an interest in the OSS had better believe that there are some policy crises looming out there in respect of the research establishment—and OSS and its staff could well be the next casualty.

TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—Mr Deputy Speaker, I appreciate the contributions made by the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus) and the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) to the debate on the Environment Protection (Alligator Rivers Region) Amendment Bill. I know that the honourable member for Gippsland was listening intently to my second reading speech whilst he was talking to his leader. I respect the honourable member for Gippsland for his ability to do both.

PARA.TAB: The advisory committee has been deliberately structured to separate the scientific aspect from the political. It can comment on but cannot change recommendations from the technical committee to the minister. The technical committee will also have the capacity to advise the minister of the continuing nature and extent of research necessary. This will be in addition to the existing scientific and political advice that the minister has available. I hope that the concerns of the honourable member for Gippsland are allayed by that structure and that his concerns now rest with no more than the newness of it all.

In respect to the honourable member's concerns about a fee for service being paid by the Ranger uranium mine, I am informed that no fee for service is being paid. The uranium export levy will be abolished as soon as an alternative is negotiated. The levy is paid under the Customs Act and is based on the amount of uranium exported. It is expected that the levy will be abolished by 1 July 1994. As I am informed, there is no impediment whatsoever to Ranger with respect to this legislation, nor have any serious concerns been expressed by Ranger. Indeed, the whole process has been designed to achieve cost savings and greater efficiencies in the administration of this particular mechanism.

More importantly, as I said in the second reading speech, this bill will provide the minister with a greater range of consultation; provide an independent review of research needed to meet the Commonwealth's environment protection objectives for the region; refine mechanisms for consulting key stakeholders; and enable the minister to seek advice from the supervising scientists on environmental matters outside the Alligator Rivers region. They are important and sensible amendments for incorporation in this bill.

I know that every member in the House is concerned not only about environmental issues in this area but also, in a wider context in Australia, about the need to ensure that development of our country proceeds in a responsible way and is not inhibited by arguments which are without substance. I know that honourable members will appreciate my remarks. I therefore commend the bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to offer my congratulations to the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett) and the members of his committee for what is a very useful contribution to the procedural debate in this parliament, a debate which has gone on for the 10 years that I have been here and which I do not doubt will go on for as long as the House exists. I am not sure whether we will find a perfect solution.

PARA.TAB: The report focuses in two main ways on some creative changes, one of these being the proposal for a main committee of the parliament which would meet separately, adjacently and in parallel to the House itself. The second suggestion is that it use the existing parliamentary committees to examine legislation. With regard to these proposals, the idea of the main committee has some flaws. I can see a real danger in that committee becoming an alternative chamber in much the same way as the Senate and the House of Representatives debates become not just confusing but almost have a dialectical tension.

Putting that into the one House could be quite counterproductive. I am not, however, suggesting that it be ruled out of order as such. The methods that have been put before us in the report do not sufficiently prescribe the idea of the main committee. It would have to be much narrower, defined and prescribed when the committee reports back to the House for the idea to take a form that would not just become a replica or a repeat performance of what occurs in the committee stages here.

However, the idea of referring some legislation to parliamentary committees has merit, but only for certain kinds of legislation. If that were at the wish of the House, that could be a useful way. But it also has some great weaknesses. The first of those, of course, is that the existing standing orders of parliamentary committees would need to be much better defined and much more clearly laid out.

Secondly, there would need to be some liaison between this House and the other place, otherwise we could have the farce of this House having a committee look at legislation—and then eventually as a House making a decision. That would then go to the Senate which would do exactly the same thing with the same people, witnesses and arguments—and, very likely, given the current political mixture, end up with an opposite decision.

We would increase the level of scepticism in the community as to the role of the parliament. In that context, if we are to look at legislation in the external sense of allowing witnesses or people to come forward to address the committee or to contribute, it would need to be done in conjunction with the Senate so that what was then resolved would be seen to be the wish of the parliament as a whole, not simply one small part—albeit in a public and, hence, potentially dramatic, way.

Two other important issues raised in the report are the hours of sitting and question time. Before I go to those, I come back to what predicated the report. What initiated the report is basically what has been happening in this chamber in recent years—or what is perceived to have been happening. I say `perceived' because it is only in recent years that the chamber has been televised in the way that it has been and that vision has been available to the media and hence to the broader community. Even though, in my view, the chamber has not changed much in the time I have been here, the way it has been perceived has been changing—and not necessarily all for the worse; in some aspects it has been for the better. Anyone watching the Senate in recent days would be highly enlightened as to the relevance of that chamber and its non-contribution to the national debate. Many of us think that the televising of proceedings has in fact been quite positive.

I think that the post-Budget period, when this chamber ruled out MPIs and censure motions, was the most productive time I have seen. We saw then more debate on legislation—and more useful and meaningful debate—than at most other times.

People talk about log jams and timetabling. What happens on most days we sit, particularly halfway through a session, is that by the time we go through the MPI, the censure motion and all the grandstanding, all the day's procedures have been pushed back to the end of the day—and then to the end of the week. Debates that were scheduled for Monday and Tuesday get pushed back to Wednesday and Thursday and those scheduled for the morning get pushed back to the night.

It is not so much a question of the rules, procedures or timetabling of the House, but of the way people behave. It is the way the rules are used. It is not so much a question of what is good about the report; the question is what openings the report gives for the forms of the House to be misused for political gain. It is not wrong to do that; it is not a sin. The opposition has every right to use the forms of the House to its advantage if it sees an advantage available. What is happening right now in the other house—the organised chaos there—is a correct use of the forms. Whether it is of political advantage is secondary, though there is no doubt that it is imposing a huge cost on the country and a huge uncertainty on the community—and it is certainly, I think, damaging the standing of the procedures of the parliament as a whole. But the fact is that the forms are available.

If we turn to the main thrust of the recommendations, the main question is not what we can do to help the parliament or the House of Representatives, but how the forms could be misused. If there were a creative strategist in the opposition of any day, could the forms be misused to disrupt, to delay or to give the appearance of incompetence?

We had the farce where, in speeches on Friday on the very report we are debating now, people were talking about the government not being in control. People were saying that the fact that we were even discussing the report on Friday afternoon was in itself a sign that the government did not have its act in order. Of course the government did not have its act in order. The people who were making sure it did not have its act in order were the opposition, with its numbers in the Senate. That those people tried to turn a situation of mischievousness and misuse of forms into somehow being a government responsibility is indicative. The fact is that the reforms proposed in the report can lend themselves quite seriously to misuse unless they are very tightly circumscribed. I have mentioned the two ways in which that can be done.

The report does not touch much on MPIs. I notice that the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), in his contribution, indicated that he thought the government could have one MPI per week. The MPIs we have seen in these sittings have been so appallingly boring, dismal and irrelevant to what is going on in the country in any serious sense that they ought to be scrapped almost entirely. The name `matters of public importance' should be changed; they are matters of political importance to the opposition only. That is what they are, basically. They are not matters of public importance. They are invariably fabricated, they are invariably factored around question time, they are invariably factored around what those opposite see as a political advantage and they do not contribute to the total knowledge of the community.

In other words, MPIs are not enlightening; they are not debates that bring new information forward. Basically, MPIs are trawling old territory over and over on the grounds that the more one says something the more people may believe it if they bother noticing. The whole role of MPIs in this place should be reconsidered.

There is scope for constructive, sensible debate on broader issues facing the nation and MPIs are not the way to do it. In that sense the report is weak because it does not address what I see as being the structural problem. The alternative is to push the MPIs to 9 o'clock or 10 o'clock at night and make them the last debate of the day so that they do not disrupt the proceedings of the House at the important times when people are active and things can be done. I am sick and tired of having the consideration of legislation pushed back every night until late at night. Numerous times my speeches and other members' speeches have been rescheduled during the day to that night and then to the next day because of the misuse of the forms that are available.

The other question of misuse concerns the hours of sitting. I think it was quite remarkable that back during those months when the prohibitions were in place the House was very effective. I have never seen it work so well. There were no censure motions and such good debate. The fact is that the margins and boundaries were set and only certain things were possible. There is an argument that the government and the opposition could come to agreement on each bill. For example, they could agree that one bill warrants four hours of debate, another warrants two hours of debate and another warrants only 15 minutes because no-one will argue against it.

There is a large amount of wasted time in this House because members speak for the sake of speaking. They are not speaking on behalf of any constituency. Basically they are filling up what they perceive to be gaps. Why do we not have a system for each bill, under which we say, `In the overall scheme of things, this bill does not warrant 35 hours of debate in the parliament and the cost involved.'? People talk about waste and government expenses, but every hour of debate in these chambers has a cost attached to it. Already there have been 41 hours of debate on Mabo in the Senate and I gather that the debate will go for 48 hours at huge cost to the taxpayers. What new information has come forward as a result of that—what new amendments and new ideas from the opposition? Basically, there has not been one amendment at all and at what cost?

Would it not be more reasonable to suggest—rather than working nine to five, nine until midnight, or whatever it might be—that for certain bills, for example, we attach a limit of four hours for debate? It would be remarkable to see how sharply that would focus members' minds on what they are putting forward. Speeches would become much more pertinent.

In one sense it is a bit academic whether the time is set at 8.30, 10 or 11 at night, because what will happen is that there will be filibustering during the day, censure motions and all the time wasting matters. The hours at night will be extended anyway. Whatever time we set, we will go beyond that time to finish off the day's business, as we have done every year for 10 years in my experience.

I suggest that the report is useful. It is a starting point rather than a finishing point. As other speakers have said, there is not much to do in Canberra. As far as I am concerned, if we are here, we are normally in the House. I agree with a 10 o'clock termination rather than 11 o'clock because at least one might get to bed at a more reasonable hour. Also, if the sitting has to be extended, then the extension time will not be that much later. If the termination time is 11 o'clock, we normally go until midnight or beyond and that becomes common. I would argue in favour of a 10 o'clock cessation.

Other members have spoken glowingly about the use of parliamentary committees. The fact is that in the scheme of things there is no time for them. How on earth can parliamentary committees work effectively when there is no time for them to sit? Quorums or divisions are likely to be called whilst they are having hearings or meetings.

One of the potential advantages mentioned in the report was that, if the parliament were serious about having committees, it should allow them to meet in a proper sense. All members of the committee should attend, but that is not the case, as we know, because of other competing duties that members and senators have. Finishing times should be prescribed for parliamentary committees. That way, our committee system would be more useful.

The question is not so much what frameworks we have, it is how we use the frameworks that are available. The existing framework could work very well if all members let it. Question time could work more quickly if ministers and questioners acted more appropriately, answers were shorter, there were fewer interruptions, fewer points of order and the questions were more intelligent. The questions are invariably loaded for stupid reasons. When we have stupid questions, we get answers which are appropriate. The forms that we have in place could work much better if we let them.

I have two ideas for the committee to consider: firstly, rethinking MPIs so that there is a constructive debate each day, or every second day, on a much broader basis than we have currently. Secondly, having an anticipated debating time for bills so that members have some idea of how long is available for debate. It currently tends to be the case that a minor amendment is given the same time for debate as a major piece of legislation. Minor amendments are discussed for hours and major legislation often gets jammed up and guillotined at the end. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Worth Ms T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The madness and uncertainty of this current sitting time highlight the need for us to be talking seriously about reforms to how we do business in this place. I congratulate the Standing Committee on Procedure headed by the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett)—who I note is in the House—on the report it has presented. On the whole, it has produced very sensible and reasonable recommendations which are long overdue.

PARA.TAB: It is both normal and sensible for any organisation or corporation to regularly review performance and procedures. Parliament should not be exempt from this process. From an historic perspective, today there are more bills debated but with the same number of sitting days. The report highlights the disparity in the legislative activities since Federation. For example, for each year from 1901 to 1911 there were 23 bills passed, with an average 25 sitting hours to debate each bill. However, in 1992 there were 264 bills, with an average of two hours to debate each bill.

It is also interesting to note that the number of federal MPs has almost doubled, with an allotment of one-tenth the debating time per bill, resulting in an excessive use of the guillotine. One hundred and thirty-two bills were guillotined in 1992. A classic example of the madness is that the Senate sat past midnight on 20 occasions in 1992. I do not know about other members, but my brain wants to shut down after midnight. It is quite obvious that adequate time is not being given to the important consideration of legislation. The honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), who will regrettably be in this House for the last time this week, said that legislation is being passed through the Senate and the House `without being given the primary treatment afforded sewage'.

Let us take the Mabo bill and the situation we find ourselves in today. This is one of the most important pieces of legislation to come before us for a long time. It is a complex bill of many pages which not only interweaves with other acts, such as the Racial Discrimination Act, but also now has more than 230 amendments. More than 90 of these amendments have come from the federal government alone. It is understandable that honourable senators want time to debate the legislation in detail, yet if we are going to have turkey for Christmas instead of native title this bill will have to be debated and cleared from the Senate chamber in a hurry. This is a striking example of important and complex legislation being hurried by the government when more attention to detail in the first place and broader consultation in the community would have avoided the debacle we see today. Page 16 of the report About time: bills, questions and working hours states:

SPEECH.PARA: The committee is also fully conscious of the committee workload already faced by Members. Nevertheless the committee does see a useful role for standing committees in enabling greater input to the legislative process from the community and interested groups and considers that the possibility of such opportunities should be explicitly provided for.

The High Court Mabo decision was handed down in June 1992. The fact that 18 months later the consequential legislation is in such tatters is a clear example that the government has badly mismanaged its business. It should have been mandatory that this legislation went before a committee prior to final debate in this place, as is recommended in the report. I could confidently predict that many of the problems may well have been ironed out if this procedure had been followed. One of the greatest strengths of the Senate is the committee system. All too often, when government members stand up in this place and mention the Senate, it is in the context of having it abolished. Committees provide an avenue for considered and proper analysis.

PARA.TAB: I am the first to admit that I have tested the limits of exhaustion this past week. I am sure I am not alone in this. If we were to take a step back and observe, we would note an element of madness about the place—perhaps not today but certainly last Friday night and Saturday. It seems self-evident that sensible sitting hours are more likely to lead to sensible decisions, which is surely what this country needs. We need to consider our health—not only that of members and senators but also that of our staff and those who run this place. Our working hours and conditions simply would not pass the test of any sensible occupational health and safety guidelines.

I suggested recently in a newspaper article that parliamentarians should keep track of the decay that this crazy lifestyle brings by each one of us having a close-up photograph taken every year. This would allow us to track the ageing process as the long hours and information overload take their toll on our health and lifestyles. As commentator for the Australian Frank Devine wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . many Members resist the abolition of marathon sittings out of sheer machismo. `Ordinary people may be prone to fatigue but watch me mate, I can go on forever'. They like to think their stamina gives them an advantage over rivals but the probability is that it gives them only the capacity to stay on their feet while virtually brain dead.
British psychiatrist Hugh Freeman writes in The Human Brain and Political Behaviour:
. . . fatigued decision-makers tend to become irritable and impatient when any doubts are raised about their proposals so that their subordinates find it prudent to keep silent.

He says that weary decision makers `make major decisions when they are not thinking clearly'. Perhaps there is a clear message in this for the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). Freeman also talks about information overload—that the constantly increasing volumes of information being received by political leaders may be placing too great a burden on the relevant processing machinery. My Senate colleague John Herron says:
Most of our body's functions show maximum activity by day and minimal activity by night . . .

He says that interfering with this rhythm affects `behaviour, alertness, reaction times and mental activity'. Senator Herron says that the politicians confined to Parliament House for most of their waking hours develop a feeling of being cut off from the community and not participating in its social life and collective responsibilities.

PARA.TAB: The report contains many recommendations for improving operations in the House and the quality of decisions we make. I believe the recommendations that will impact most on us will be those relating to sitting hours. Revised sitting patterns would see the House sitting for an additional day each fortnight and rising no later than 8 p.m. Question time would be extended from 45 minutes to an hour. To cut time, ministers will be forced to shorten their long-winded answers, with a requirement of 16 questions to be asked each day.

There are those among us who ask: how will we spend our evenings under such arrangements? There may still be committee meetings. There will still be work to be done. But it will allow members a choice about when they have an early night, when they have a relaxing evening meal and when they will be able to meet with public servants and diplomats who also live in Canberra.

For my own part—and I acknowledge it is stating the obvious—we need time to be able to read and absorb and develop new ideas. We need to spend quality time in the electorate. We also need to have some time to put aside for our committee work, which I have discovered can be most productive. Importantly, we need time to work well and effectively. We will need to have time for ourselves and time for our families.

I also observe that so often some grandstanding takes place in this House. Perhaps it is not always necessary for honourable members to speak for 20 minutes. I feel that I have been able to make some important points in this speech yet, as an example of the fact that we do not always need to take so much time, I shall not use my full time today. I commend the thrust of the recommendations in the report to the House but, in doing so, note the concerns of the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) and the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing) which are detailed in the minority report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I notice that the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett) is here today. I congratulate him on the work that he has put into this report. It certainly recognises the difficulties and constraints that we face when we start talking about change here. There are two aspects to change. One is the good working of this place and the other is the impact it has on Australian people generally. I do not think it would be an exaggeration to say that people in the community who do not have a great knowledge of the way parliament works regard this place as a joke and regard us as part of a circus. To some extent, that is driven by the procedures that we carry on with here, including question time, the public side of parliament, and the general running of parliament.

PARA.TAB: One of the public's great criticisms of politicians—I see and hear this time and time again—is that we are all out of touch and do not have a clue about what people are really thinking. I think that statement has some credibility. I come to Canberra and hear about the major arguments that make the national headlines, but when I go home and talk to people in the streets I find that they do not have a clue about them and are not at all interested. For instance, the furore not so long ago over pay TV was on the front page of the newspapers every day. It was debated in this House and every question was about it. The press ran it like billyo. I suppose the press had a vested interest in that matter because it involves its industry—

TALK.START.PARA: —They are obsessed by it.

—Yes, they are obsessed by it. Yet when I go up to Whiporie or Rappville or somewhere else up my way, I find that the people there think that pay TV involves putting two bob in the slot for it to work. That is what gives them the idea that we are out of touch.

PARA.TAB: Then we had the great debate about foreign ownership of the media, which I guess is important. But, try as we may, we cannot get raised in the media the issue of foreign ownership of our other industries. I have tried a number of times. For instance, there are no limits to foreign ownership of our meat industry, yet the press is not interested in that. The opposition is not interested in it because it sees the financial ramifications. We have got a limited interest in it through the FIRB. But when we look at the issue of foreign ownership of the media, it is major news every time. So I think there is a bit of credibility to the view that people have of us that we are out of touch with them, and we reinforce that all the time.

We could change that view if politicians were able to be in their electorates more, talk to people more and raise the issues that the people think are important. In that way we would not be seen to be in Canberra so much simply talking on issues that are raised by the national media. It is hard to know whether the media raises a matter first or we do. To a great extent I think we try to outguess each other. From the questions that the opposition asks at question time and the issues that we raise I think we try to predict what the media is going to run with. We try to predict what the media wants to hear, how it wants to hear it and what it is likely to give us a run on. I suppose I do it myself at home, but it is not a really good way of getting to the issues that are important, so we miss out a lot.

Any change is good. I should be the last person to talk about procedures because very few honourable members know less about the procedures of this place than I do. I have never made a study of it. The report's recommendation of the establishment of a separate committee is a good idea because it recognises that non-controversial bills can be separated from controversial ones. Going a step further, one could ask whether we could regulate voting times on such bills. Such a move would be a major step forward because many honourable members find their time spent confined to Parliament House to be non-productive. Honourable members would benefit from having the flexibility of doing things outside this place without having to be confined to Parliament House. At present, honourable members are confined to Parliament House for all the hours that the House sits, simply because somebody might want to vote on an issue—although voting is important because that is the end result. The report recognises that the non-controversial can be separated from the controversial. I think that is possible.

The report also recommends that question time last at least 45 minutes, with perhaps two sessions. Ministers should be limited in the time they take to answer questions. But it would be very hard to do that in a qualitative way because quality answers demand quality questions. A question aimed at political point scoring will not elicit a quality answer but the answer that such a question deserves. People often value the answers rather than look at the questions and the answers and say, `A low quality question deserves a low quality answer'. Question time creates the public image of this place. It would be a major step forward to limit the time taken by ministers to answer questions so that the information sought by the question is put succinctly and credibly rather than in a point scoring fashion, which is really the result of poor quality questioning.

Another recommendation is that the Speaker be given the power to sin-bin honourable members for disorderly conduct. I do not think that would have much effect. In fact, some honourable members, particularly those on the other side—I would not presume to name them—would wear being kicked out once in a while with no further penalty as a badge of honour. Another worthy recommendation concerns placing a limit on the time taken to answer a question on notice. Any honourable member who puts a question on notice to a minister deserves a reply within a reasonable time.

There are some real problems now with the days and hours of sitting. There will be more problems with the proposed hours of sitting. For instance, should we finish at 6.30 p.m. on Thursday, country members who might travel for five or six hours to get here could not travel home—so they would get home at midday Friday or later, and have to return on Sunday. It would hardly be worth going home; yet, as I said earlier, that is where so much of the real work is for members.

I would prefer the hours of sitting to be in blocks so that we sat for seven or eight days at a time, including the weekend. Then we would be able to have a reasonable break, or we could add the weekend onto the two weeks or week in between. Although it is nice to get home on that intervening weekend, it really is wasted time. I view an eight-day sitting, all in a block—even though it is over a weekend—as being to far better effect, particularly when we are not sitting the late hours.

It would be pretty hard to have a seven or eight-day sitting whilst sitting until 11, 12, or 1 o'clock in the morning. But if we were sitting until only 8 o'clock in the evening it would be possible to put that seven or eight-day sitting together—and include the weekend. It is my view that the intervening weekend is really wasted time for a lot of members because of the travelling involved. The time would be spent much more effectively in that way.

As I said, the issues raise problems for people who work here, but the point is really for members of parliament to try to use their time effectively. It is not used effectively now; certainly in my case it is not. It reminds me very much of being at school. I spent quite a few years at boarding school—which I did not like at all—and this is much the same sort of situation. One is driven completely by bells and procedures—with no flexibility and no real chance to use one's time as effectively as one might like.

Changes can be made to make this program more effective. Many of the changes suggested in the report are worth while. I would like to see it go a hell of a lot further than it has gone, but I also recognise, as does the honourable member for Bonython—given that there has been very little change over many years—that the ability to achieve these changes is almost not there because of political influences and people wanting their own way all the time.

The other point I would like to make is in regard to the number of acts passed per year. When we look at the table we see the number has risen dramatically; and I notice the primary industry portfolio accounts for quite a percentage. Perhaps one of the reasons is that repeat acts, relating to levies and those types of things, have to be presented every year.

A lot of that could be done by regulation—and looked at for longer than a year. The minister could regulate it within certain parameters. There could be a five-year period before it comes back. That is one way of doing it. A lot of those acts passed each year come up time and time again. We should look at the longer term rather than the very short term we look at both politically and on the issues now. If we were able to look at the longer term on so many of those things we would be a lot better off. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I commence my remarks on this discussion of the report of the Standing Committee on Procedure by congratulating the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett) and his committee on the work that they have done. I have taken the opportunity to read nearly all—I have not read every word—of the report that it has produced. It is a very good document and it will perhaps leave the impression of the honourable member for Bonython on the parliament for longer than he will be a member of the parliament. I wish him all the very best in his new career in some faraway port.

PARA.TAB: This is an interesting debate. I have listened to all of the people who have spoken to date in this procedures debate—I have a considerable interest in it—and it is interesting to note that both brand new members and old members have spoken. Some would say that the new members really have very little to contribute because they do not know much about the workings of this House, its traditions and customs and the things that it has to achieve over a period. Whilst that may be true, it is worth listening to their comments because they bring to this place and to this debate a fresh view—one not rolled up in the status quo.

For those of us who have been here for many years, we tend to think that the status quo is good simply because we are used to it. These new members can bring to this debate a totally different viewpoint from which to consider these procedural discussions. So their contributions have been worth while as, indeed, have been the contributions from longer serving members. I was particularly interested to listen to the comments of the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair). Being the father of the House, with 30 years of experience here in the federal parliament and several years of experience in the New South Wales parliament, he can probably bring a broader and deeper viewpoint to the debate than anyone else in this chamber. Each of us has a contribution to make, and I am pleased to see that so many people have listed themselves for the debate.

Trying to come up with what is right, as the honourable member for Bonython and his committee have tried to do, is incredibly difficult. One would have to have the wisdom of Solomon to achieve the task of pleasing everybody. Indeed, from my experience over the years, one cannot hope to please everybody in this House. With the arrangements that it operates under, it is simply impossible. Each and every one of us has different needs. Each and every one of us comes from a different part of Australia. We have different family arrangements, different methods of operation in our own electorates and different roles to play in the parliament. So it is simply impossible to please everybody. What I think has been achieved in the recommendations brought down by the committee will please most of the people most of the time. For that reason, I say well done to the members of the committee and its chairman, because pleasing everyone is a task that is very difficult to achieve.

It is quite interesting to consider the reasons we needed to bring down this sort of report. We have had a change in the way in which this parliament has operated over the years. We have moved from the old Parliament House to the new Parliament House. Whilst that should technically not have made any difference, it has made a difference. The fact is that the parliament is now televised; it was not televised in the old Parliament House. We did not have the technical capacity to do it. Here we have that capacity. Elements of the proceedings of parliament are now televised in a way that most of us are not particularly pleased about—we do not think it gives a proper viewing of what happens in the parliament—but at least it is now televised. That has changed the way in which critical aspects of the parliament operate. For example, I think question time has changed since we have come here and the place has been televised. Of course, the physical changes have also affected the way in which the parliament works. As I think the right honourable member for New England pointed out, this chamber is not as good a debating chamber as the chamber in the old House where we were much closer to each other and we felt there was an intimacy that promoted an exchange within the chamber that does not happen here. That is one reason.

I think the other reason we need this report is that the executive of the parliament has had a change in attitude over the years. That is best exhibited by the way in which question time operates. I believe the executive abuses the opportunities presented by question time. I have heard honourable members from the other side of the House say that this is, in part, a product of the questions that are put to ministers. But, ultimately, I think the blame rests with the executive, which takes up 99 per cent of the time during question time. It needs to take the lead in this area.

Over the last few years the executive has treated the parliament with disdain. This is particularly true of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). I do not think he loves the parliament; indeed, I think he treats the parliament as something he has to live through in order to be Prime Minister. That has had an influence.

This attitude has also come about because of the length of time the government has been in office. It is interesting to note that this is about the third generation of ministry since the Labor Party came to power 11 years ago. And with each generation of ministry, the ministers have become more arrogant. Some honourable members will remember the very early days of this Labor government when the ministers, who had been in opposition for many years, had an appreciation of what it was like to be in opposition. As those ministers left the ministry and people who had known only government became ministers, the ministry became far more arrogant and less tolerant in the way in which it operated.

This phenomenon seems to be a product of being in government for a long time. No doubt honourable members on the other side of the House would make the point that this was the case when our lot were in government from 1975 to 1983 and prior to 1972. There is no question that a lengthy period in office tends to make the government of the day less tolerant and more arrogant. Therefore, that is reflected in the way in which the House operates. That is another reason why we need to make some changes.

If we treated the House with its due respect and maintained the standing orders in the spirit in which they were made, there would be very little to debate with regard to this matter. There would not be much need for change. The only thing we could possibly be debating today would be the hours of the sitting of the House as opposed to matters relating to the management of question time, the issue of relevance, a second chamber and so forth.

That we are debating these procedural changes reflects the fact that the people in this House have not maintained the spirit of the standing orders to the degree we would have liked. It boils down to one critical element: all of the procedures and standing orders of the parliament are really only as good as the people who work within the parliament. It all depends on how effectively they want the standing orders to work. I think it is important for us as members of parliament to realise that all the standing orders and procedures will not overcome a failure by members of the parliament to make the parliament work. It is not up to the standing orders and the procedures; it is up to us to make the parliament work effectively.

I turn to question time, the proceeding which probably attracts the most attention and which is the area of most contention. When I first came into the parliament in 1984 we used to have about 20 questions a day—10 questions from the government and 10 from the opposition. We are now lucky to get 10 questions in total—five from the opposition and five from the government. The reason for that is that answers are simply too long. I note that the honourable member for Bonython made this clear in the report. I think there is only one answer to this problem—we need to impose a time limit on the answers given by ministers.

In some instances, a time limit can reduce the effectiveness of question time, because the purpose of question time is to seek information. If a limit is put on the time available for information to be provided, it can actually be quite counterproductive. However, the only way we will ever overcome the problem of lengthy answers and the other problem of question time—that of relevancy—is to have a time limit on answers. If a minister is doing the right thing and providing genuine information, and if it is the wish of the House to extend his or her time, that can be done simply by moving that the minister be given additional time to answer.

I believe that question time in the Senate works far more effectively than it does in the House of Representatives. For that reason there should be some sort of limit on the answers given by ministers. That is the way to solve the problem. It also partly solves the problem of relevancy.

Over the years, I have seen answers becoming less and less relevant. Ministers use the opportunity of question time to wax lyrical on any subject that takes their fancy. Their answers bear no resemblance to the questions put to them. Indeed, if we ask them about the weather we are likely to get an answer about the football. That is the extent of the relevance of some answers at question time over the last few years.

Judging what is relevant is a tall order for any Speaker because relevance is a matter of opinion. Who are we to know exactly what is relevant. What is relevant to me may not be relevant to someone else. It is asking a lot of a Speaker to judge that, although over the years, Speakers have done their best—some doing better than others. A time limit is a simple way to overcome the problem of relevancy. The discipline of a time limit would focus ministers on being more relevant in their answers than they have been in the past.

Hopefully, a time limit will be put in place. Then, if ministers want to wax lyrical on whatever subject takes their fancy, there is an opportunity for them under standing orders to do so by way of ministerial statement. There has been a great falling off in the number of ministerial statements delivered in the House. They could be used more effectively without the time of the House being wasted.

The other matter of interest to me relates to the position of the Speaker. For the last few years I have been a strong supporter of the need to have a permanent Speaker in the House. I believe that no matter which party is in government the Speaker should remain the Speaker until it is time for his or her retirement from the parliament or until his or her voluntary retirement from the post. That would give Speakers a sense of security that they do not have at the present time.

I also believe that the Deputy Speaker should be a member of a party opposite to that of which the Speaker is a member. In other words, if we had a Labor Speaker we would have a coalition Deputy Speaker. That is one way of providing a degree of balance to the chair. The report has recommended the appointment of a second Deputy Speaker from the opposing or non-government party. I support that recommendation. I also note the role it recommends for the second Deputy Speaker in the proposed second chamber.

I support the establishment of a second chamber. It is ridiculous that we are restricted in debate on contentious issues that come before this House while we have all the time in the world to debate matters that are non-contentious. Non-contentious bills should be channelled off to a second chamber for debate as honourable members see fit, and brought into the House for final passage. That would allow the main chamber greater opportunity and time for debating the more contentious items of business, satisfying the need of all honourable members to express their views on the very important issues.

As far as sitting hours are concerned, I am actually quite happy with the present arrangement. I am used to it. I think we all become accustomed to the weird hours under which this place operates. When I was first elected I could not cope for the first few months—I could not cope with sitting till midnight. I could not get over the fact that people 20 and 30 years my senior, such as Ralph Hunt, all seemed bright as buttons at midnight. Sooner or later we all seem to get used to it.

However, I do take the advice of more experienced and expert people on health matters, such as Dr John Herron, a senator in the other place, who tells me that no matter how used we get to these hours they still do not do us any good. On the basis of their advice and the advice of others, I think trying the hours that have been recommended is worth while. For that reason, I support the change in hours. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —(4.40 p.m.)—My name is Jim. I am a workaholic. I could tell honourable members what my disease has done to me, my family and my job. Some months ago I attended a meeting of Alcoholics Anonymous and my dissimilarity with the people there was not as great as I had anticipated before I went there. I realised that the sort of disease they have can be a disease of all of us. I have heard of an organisation called workaholics anonymous. I have never contacted it because I have not had time.

PARA.TAB: I want to dwell on the point that was made towards the end of the speech of the honourable member for Hume (Mr Sharp), because I think the timing that he mentioned and the message that he got from Dr John Herron we have also heard from other medical practitioners who have been in this place, such as Dr Dick Klugman and Dr Ric Charlesworth, who sat on this side of the House.

I am sure that most medical practitioners would agree that what we are doing is silly and that we do not always realise it.
