I have been thinking more recently about whether I should put my job on the line and retire so that I can have the sort of life I want to have in retirement, whether I should absent myself from sessions, as some honourable members have done rather cunningly and got away with it—they have just refused to turn up—or whether we should adopt the report's recommendations as we have them here on the hours of operation.

At the moment we can, if we are lucky, work from 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. once a fortnight. More often we work from 2.00 p.m. to 11 p.m. or 10 a.m. to 11 p.m. Sometimes we work until midnight and occasionally we work until 3 or 4 in the morning. Occasionally one of the houses goes all night. This sort of work is unhealthy.

Honourable members can pontificate about convenience and getting home, but they sound just like the smokers who say, `We all have to die of something' or `I do not believe the so-called proof that smoking is bad'. They are still defiant. They are still not accepting it. They sound like alcoholics who have that dependent relationship that I was talking about, or long-term inmates of our gaols who have never known anything else. I would not trust myself out there. In fact, some of them when they are released put a brick through a window or do other things so that they can go back because they feel insecure out of gaol. Some of us get like that.

Honourable members have marriage breakdowns, they have heart attacks and their performance drops, but do they blame their hours of work? It seems to me, having listened to some of the speeches here, that they do not. Some of them say, for instance, `I would rather have long hours here and get home sooner'. I would not mind hearing the views of their spouses or their families because I think a lot of honourable members would just go to sleep for a whole day when they get home and would not be of much use anyway.

Some honourable members say, `I wouldn't know what to do after 8 o'clock at night if we stopped at 8 o'clock at night. I would have nothing to do'. Some of them have said that to me. Again, I think they are not acknowledging the medical evidence. The New England Journal of Medicine points out:

Humans are the only species that is routinely active at a time of great propensity for sleep and that attempts to sleep at the time of increased physiologic arousal. This behavioural override of circadian physiologic signals is a hallmark of modern civilization; it characterizes not only shift workers but also millions of travelers who fly into different time zones.

SPEECH.PARA: It amazes me that the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett), who has led this report—an excellent report—and other honourable members, such as the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin), the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins), and Senator Cook, members who have served as ministers for trade, have been able to cope and perform so well. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) paid them great compliment, and due compliment, just the other day for the work that they did. However, it amazes me how they have coped when they were flying in different time zones. The article continues:

Besides its implications for the well-being of the persons involved, this conflict with the circadian system has important social and economic implications, because night work is associated with substantial decrements in performance and vigilance, resulting in diminished productivity and increased accident rates. Thus, there is a crucial need for strategies that could improve physiologic adaptation to conditions in which an enforced activity-rest cycle conflicts with endogenous circadian rhythmicity.
That is a very important point from the New England Journal of Medicine. Cecil's Textbook of Medicines claims on page 2356 that 20 per cent of people cannot tolerate shift work.

PARA.TAB: We have what are called circadian rhythms, which I have mentioned. They are slightly more than 24 hours long, they are re-set daily by light and time cues. There are day and night cycles, and in those cycles body temperature is affected, with the body temperature being lowest at about 3.30 a.m. and highest at 7.30 p.m., on average. Heart rate, blood pressure, ventilatory capacity, gastrointestinal activity and the excretion of electrolytes in urine are affected. These activities are higher during the day—and they are higher still for introverts like me—and peak in the late afternoon. There is a trough early in the morning. The peak and the trough coincide with wakefulness and sleep. I quote again from the New England Journal of Medicine of 3 May 1990:

SPEECH.PARA: Night work, which is voluntarily accepted by millions of workers in industrialized countries, is a major health hazard, involving an increased risk of cardio-vascular illness, gastrointestinal disorders, infertility and insomnia. The medical consequences of night work are associated with chronic misalignment of physiologic circadian rhythms and the activity-rest cycle. Indeed . . . several studies have shown that workers on permanent or rotating night shifts generally do not adapt to these schedules, even after several years. The inability to adapt appears to be due to the fact that the endogenous timing system that drives circadian rhythms is exposed to conflicting signals from the imposed activity-rest cycle, the natural light-dark cycle, and the schedule of social activities outside the workplace.
Walker, in The Human Aspects of Shiftwork, says:
Politicians and businessmen are advised to be careful in their decision making which may be imperfect at these times.

Walker is talking about jet lag, but he compares the effects of jet lag with those of night work and shift work. I believe that our decision making is impaired when we try to work at night and make decisions at night. Walker points out that the most important synchronisers in our timing are light and darkness, and our social habits, but that there are also secondary synchronisers such as ambient temperature. He reports results of a survey which indicated some drop in productivity on night shift in 39 per cent of workplaces. The productivity was much less for only three per cent, but there was a perceived effect in 39 per cent of workplaces.

PARA.TAB: Walker also points out that there are two different types of people. There are the morning types—and I regard myself as one of those—who experience most interference to sleep when they work at night, and there are those who are least affected when they work at night. They are the evening types or the types who do not wake up very easily in the mornings and find the evenings more suitable for work. There are two different types of people.
Even if the late work affects only some types of people, surely we can come to the sort of compromise that the committee has reached. I believe its suggested hours accommodates both types.
Dr Yossie Berger, a worker with the Australian Workers Union, pointed out the following during an interview on the 7.30 Report on 2 January 1991:

SPEECH.PARA: Essentially, what happens is that the internal clock or the internal drumbeat—if you could call it that—of the mechanisms, the hormones, is out of sync; it's not synchronised with the outside world. When the light is high and intense outside, then your hormones are meant to do one thing; they're doing the opposite. That has a deleterious effect on your system, the various systems.
She continues:

The international literature reports that level of gastrointestinal diseases, ulcerations are substantially higher amongst people doing shift work. Also there are reports now, from Austria and America, that there are strong suggestions that heart disease, various ischaemic disease and cardiac disease, are also higher amongst shift workers.

Walker points out in his book The Human Aspects of Shiftwork that more serious accidents involving loss of working time for more than 15 days, or partial or total incapacity, are likely to occur with people who work at night. All accidents are slightly higher, but the more serious ones are perceptibly higher. Also, there is a small but consistent tendency for ex-shift workers who worked at night to have a higher mortality.

PARA.TAB: Walker also points out from a survey of persons involved in the navy that they are able to complete interesting tasks fairly well, even when they have been awake for up to 40 hours, but they are unable to complete uninteresting tasks after long periods of sleep deprivation. Honourable members would have to admit that some of our tasks, important as they are, can be uninteresting as they drag on. Walker also points out how workers can suffer in a marriage, in their companionship, the amount of assistance they give with housework at home, relaxation, protection of the family, mutual understanding within the family, decision making and sexual relations.

I have dwelt at length on the times that this House operates. I strongly support the proposal by the committee for an 8 p.m. close and a 6.30 p.m. finish on Thursdays. These times are very sensible. There is nothing wrong with people having policy and other committee meetings. At least it will not need to be every night and it can be a personal decision made by the members.

The point I want to make is that it is the newer members, such as the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Knott), who feel the effects of the long hours. We have listened to medical practitioners who have been in this place and they substantially support the views of the committee. We ought to look at the example set by the medical practitioners who have been in this place and who have strongly objected to the hours. I can recall Dr Doug Everingham, the former member for Capricornia, giving very strong emphasis to the importance of closing this parliament down earlier.

I will have to make a decision within the next few years as to whether I should retire or play the wag from this place. Or will this House give us the opportunity to adopt the recommendations in the report concerning the hours of operation before the whip gives me a good talking to?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I would like to congratulate the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett) on the very thoughtful report that he and his committee, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Procedure, have produced entitled About time: bills, questions and working hours. I suspect that many of the government's problems concerning Mabo and many other matters would not have occurred had the honourable member for Bonython and other former ministers such as the honourable member for Holt (Mr Duffy), the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) and the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) still been in the ministry.

PARA.TAB: However, all is not lost. The former minister, the honourable member for Bonython, has been largely responsible for the production of this report and I hope that the parliament and the government look seriously at it. To an extent over recent years there has been a tug of war between the executive and the legislature. Unfortunately, in most cases the executive seems to win. Honourable members will recall that I was privileged to serve in the parliament from 1984 until 1987. I have noticed some changes in the period when I was away and, indeed, after I returned after the March election.

I give the government some credit for giving private members more time for their business. I know that the 90-second statements that we presently have on Thursday—and which I would like to see very much more often—have given honourable members on both sides of the House a brief opportunity on a regular basis to raise matters of interest to them and of interest and concern to their electorates. I understand also that there is now more time allocated for private members business on a Thursday. Honourable members can debate motions and occasionally private members' bills. My recollection is that honourable members did not have that same opportunity when I was in parliament before.

There are very many good recommendations in the report but it is not a bipartisan report. A minority report has been produced by opposition members, but certainly the thrust of the report has been endorsed and supported by most members in the House. However, we ought also take note that, although a majority of the committee has brought down the report, there is no certainty that the report will be implemented. One only has to look at the Speaker's humiliation a few short weeks ago when the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings brought down its report, which was widely accepted. Indeed, in my view had that report been implemented in its totality, the quality of debate would have improved and the standing of the parliament would have been higher throughout the nation. I hope that the honourable member for Bonython does not suffer the same fate with this report as did Mr Speaker.

During the first decade of federation, on average 23 bills a year were put through the parliament and I understand that each of them took an average of 25 sitting hours to deal with. At the moment in this nation we must regard legislation as a good thing because we seem to have a lot of it. In 1992, 264 acts were passed. But, sadly, because of the pressure of business and the government's refusal to have an adequate number of sitting days and hours, each of those bills had a debating time of just over two hours. The UK parliament sits very much more often and it deals with fewer bills.

However, I am opposed to the second chamber proposal outlined in the report. I suggest to the government that probably what we need is not two chambers, but less legislation and fewer bills. If we were able to reduce the amount of legislation going through the parliament, then the citizens of this nation would be a lot freer. Possibly we should have a session just to repeal some legislation. The problem is the amount of legislation. The chairman of the committee, the honourable member for Bonython, saw the solution to this increase in legislation as having two committees. Of course, the other alternative would be to have less legislation and business.

I wish to deal with a few matters covered in the report. Everyone on both sides of the House agrees that question time simply does not work in this place. I understand the government will say that it knows that question time does not really work as well as the opposition would like. Had we won the election in March, the tables would have been turned; we would have been satisfied with the procedures and the present government—which would have become the opposition—would have been dissatisfied.

As parliamentarians, it is time we take a stand for the quality of performance and debate in this place. It is very important that the Australian people get fair value for the many dollars they pay to keep this place running. Question time is a disaster. At the present time, we find that many ministers give longwinded answers. Many of those answers are ministerial statements under the guise of answers. Ministerial statements appear to have officially disappeared, but they continue in the form of longwinded answers. When a minister such as Minister Kelly is on the ropes, the message goes out to the frontbenchers, `Filibuster, take as long as you can, squander and waste as much question time as you can and some way or another we'll get through this without the minister being sacked'—as she should have been because of the sports rorts affair.

Even when we do not have ministers under great stress, we still find that a tradition has grown up in this place whereby answers are longwinded, not relevant and do not even answer the question. I am very pleased that the honourable member for Bonython and his committee have included a requirement that question time should be at least 45 minutes; although I would prefer at least 60 minutes, or two periods of 30 minutes with a minimum number of questions—16, I think.

The proposal for supplementary questions is excellent. We can all recall how the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly) was, in effect, reeling from the opposition attack in recent times. Had it been possible for honourable members asking a question of the minister to follow up with a supplementary question, the people and the parliament might have obtained the answers they were entitled to.

It is also important that question time is not held too late to be covered on the various news services. If it is too late, a lot of the purpose of question time—which is to obtain information from ministers—will not be achieved. There has been a suggestion that ministers go on and on with their answers because of the disruption from this side of the House. The reality—and I can see the honourable member for Charlton nodding; he would probably agree with me—is a chicken and egg situation. If a question were asked of a minister, and a concise answer conveying information were given, there would be no reason for us to become restless or take the very appropriate points of order so regularly taken by us. It is time to go back to the drawing board and look at this whole question. I commend the committee on its suggestions.

Most honourable members will recall the contribution made by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) last week in this debate when he said that the worst job in this place is to be a government backbencher. The second worst job is to be an opposition backbencher. The real problem that all backbench members have is that these days we get very few opportunities to ask questions. My observation is that the government has a list of structured questions on its side of the parliament. The honourable member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay) hands out the lists of those Labor backbench members who are to ask questions without notice—or supposedly without notice—of ministers. In reality, most of them are dorothy dixers. That is probably the way it was while we were in office.

Government members will notice that our whips go around and hand out to us a similar list of questions. Unfortunately, many of our questions are taken up by the frontbench, so the backbenchers get little opportunity to ask questions. I know that both sides could say, `Okay, we're going to have a limited number of structured questions and then there will be opportunities for the backbench', but it never seems to happen.

During my previous term in the parliament, I noticed a similar situation. It is an ongoing problem, but it should be looked at. Question time is designed to get answers from ministers. Quite often, an unstructured question from an opposition backbencher can throw a minister in a way that questions from the frontbench never seem to. A lot of backbenchers on both sides of the House feel that

SPEECH.PARA: they are division fodder. Ministers and opposition executive members would probably agree—in a private moment—that that is the case. Backbenchers are required to come in and vote. Unfortunately, most of the activity in the parliament is handled by those on the frontbench on both sides.

PARA.TAB: I am opposed to the rostering of ministers. I can understand that if the parliament were sitting much more it would be reasonable for the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) not to be here every day. For instance, at Westminster, where the parliament sits many days, it is perfectly reasonable for the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom not to be in the parliament every day. Because we sit such a small number of days—I think we sit for approximately 60 or 70 days, or have done in the past—I do not believe that it is at all unreasonable for the Prime Minister and all ministers to be in the parliament, so they may be held to account for the government's decisions.

It is a very good idea to give more power to the Speaker, provided the neutrality of the Speaker can be guaranteed. I am also attracted to the UK proposition where the Speaker is apolitical; resigns from his or her party; has no further party involvement; and, at the next election, his or her seat is not contested by the major parties. The right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), the father of the House, mentioned guaranteeing the endorsement of Speakers if we do not follow the complete UK system. In my view, that would not be adequate to guarantee neutrality.

In the UK, Speakers usually see this position as the culmination of a parliamentary career. I believe that a retiring Speaker is elevated to the peerage and made a viscount. In Australia, our Speakers often look at the speakership as part of a career path. The honourable member for Watson has become the government whip—I am not certain whether he sees that as a step up or down. Our Speaker could have ministerial capacities. I would not be surprised to see him move in that direction in the future.

Labor Speakers find it very hard to be as neutral as Liberal-National Party Speakers. All of them would have eyes on the precedent of Speaker Cope during the time of the Whitlam government. It is a positive step to give extra sanctions to Speakers to enable them to order honourable members from the House for a short period. We might even see some government members sent out for a short time.

TALK.START.PARA: —They never misbehave.

—I do not know whether the people of Australia would agree with the honourable member for Charlton, but I think the Speaker should be able to discipline honourable members for a short space of time when their conduct does not require them to be banished for a longer period. My view is that questions on notice appear to be answered more promptly than when I was in the parliament before, but the requirements for the Speaker to inquire of the minister if there has been an undue delay, as outlined by the committee, is a very positive step.

PARA.TAB: Other members have concentrated on the days and hours of sitting. Not only are we here for a very long time, but many of us have to travel a long way. It took me 4 1/2 hours to get here today. My colleague the honourable member for Cowan (Mr Evans) comes from Western Australia and travels for half a day to get here. That should also be considered in addition to the time we are in the parliament. It is a great idea to finish at 8 p.m, although it is important that we continue the adjournment debate because that gives honourable members the opportunity to raise matters of local concern. Stress on honourable members and health problems are also a major worry.

In summing up, the honourable member for Bonython and his committee have done a great job. It is a very positive step forward. I hope the government seriously looks at what the committee has suggested. Let us face it: we owe it to the people of Australia to make this place work. It is not working now. I hope that the committee report does not suffer the same fate as the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings suffered a short time ago. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to join with those honourable members who have congratulated my good friend and colleague the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett) for his chairing of the Standing Committee on Procedure and bringing forward a report which certainly has attracted the attention of honourable members, as it should, and which has pointed out a number of very useful directions in which to proceed. Those honourable members from both sides of the parliament who worked with the honourable member for Bonython are also deserving of congratulations for the obvious effort that they put into compiling a report of that kind.

PARA.TAB: Anything that makes this place operate more efficiently makes liberal democracy, as we understand it and as it operates in Australia, perform more efficiently as well. If this place is to operate efficiently, then the members of it need to be able to operate efficiently. To a very large extent, that is the type of question which has been addressed by the honourable member for Bonython and his committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —But will the government take notice of the report?

—The honourable member for Fisher, who made a very valuable contribution to this discussion, raises the question as to whether or not the government will take note of the report. I hope so. I do not know whether there is any guarantee; nor should there be any guarantee that this government, or any government, would accept in total all the details contained in any report of this kind.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Fisher, in his contribution, indicated that there were some elements of the report with which he could not agree and which he would not be prepared to support. He also indicated that there were other elements that he would be prepared to support. One thing that interested me was that he endorsed the proposed 8 o'clock rising, but he did not endorse the proposal that there be a main committee. How can we squeeze—apart from reducing legislation, as he suggested—more work into less time without providing the facilities for that extra work to be undertaken? I do not know. But that is one of a number of questions which will be addressed in the course of these issues being canvassed, and with sensible solutions and arrangements hopefully arising from them.

TALK.START.PARA: —But the report doesn't suggest substantially reduced sitting hours.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. N.B. Reid)—Order! The honourable member for Charlton will address his remarks through the chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly through you, Mr Deputy Speaker; sometimes through you to the honourable member for Fisher. When we talk of the efficiency of this place, it is often not understood well enough by people outside the parliament—I think it is understood well enough by members of the parliament—just how important this institution is.

PARA.TAB: Australia, as a continent, consists of seven million square kilometres. The most important area of that seven million square kilometres in terms of ensuring that Australia's liberal democracy is strong, is strengthened and operates properly is the area contained within these walls—this chamber. Australians, no matter what concerns they have, can generally feel confident that their concerns will, at some time, be expressed in this place by someone. If they feel that that is the case, then I think that there is less likelihood that the frustrations of people concerned about issues will rise to the point where they find it necessary—in order to express their indignation, concern, or anger—to go out on to the streets and to break windows, burn cars, fire guns and use explosives.

For example, in the top floor of the gallery we have a glass observation section. This makes it possible for the school children of Australia to come in and witness honourable members of this chamber, the officers of this chamber, and the people who assist in the operation of this chamber, performing the functions which take place within these four walls. That would not be there unless there was a recognition of the importance of this place.

We also have the public gallery. This makes it possible for people to come in here, at any time, to see the way in which this place and their members perform. I do not know whether there are any constituents from Charlton in the public gallery or anywhere around here at the present time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Chifley reminds me that the constituents of Charlton are among the best informed constituents anywhere in Australia. They exercise wonderful political judgment, they are extremely perceptive as far as politics is concerned, and they vote very well. Sometimes they come here and make the observation afterwards that one person was speaking; one member was on the opposition side; the clerks were always in attendance; the Speaker or the Chairman was in position; the Hansard reporter was there; but where were the rest of the people who should be there? They believe that their members, and members generally, should be in this chamber attending to the legislation and representing the interests of their constituents.

PARA.TAB: What sorts of things are going on? Why is it not possible for people, including people like me, who enjoy this chamber, not to be here as often as they would like? If I were in this chamber as much as I would like to be, that would be an indication of self-indulgent selfishness. I would be here simply because I enjoyed the chamber. If I were here, I would not be doing all of those things that are rightfully expected, but not legally required, of me as a member of the parliament. Honourable members have to deal with all of the committee work which takes place within this building; all of the correspondence that they have to attend to; constituent problems, irrespective of how efficient their electorate staff happen to be back in their electorates; preparations for debates; all of the reading that they need to undertake; all of the reports that they need to go through. At the end of the day, after 11 o'clock, how often do honourable members say, `I will not go home yet; I will catch up with my reading of the day's newspapers.'? If it is as often for them as it is for me, then it is very often indeed. All of those things have to be attended to.

I would not want my constituents, every time they came down to Canberra, to see me sitting in this chamber. If I were sitting here, they would need to be asking themselves, `Why is he not out there in his office, or around in the committee rooms, or elsewhere in this building, doing the things that will make his job more effective and, as a result, make our representation more effective?'. That is another reason that this place needs to operate efficiently.

There are a lot of things wrong with the system. For example, ministers—I found this during the period I was minister, and this applies to all ministers—can have highly paid bureaucrats in their offices canvassing issues, reporting to them, taking back their concerns, and discussing ways through policy and legislation. Ministers can have business people or interest groups meeting with them in their rooms. There are the ministers' advisers and personal staff, and all of the work that they are involved in. Ministers could be going through, as I say, reports, submissions, correspondence, programs, projects, policy developments—all of those things.

Then the bells ring and the ministers have to leave those highly paid bureaucrats, business people and the leading people of major corporations or trade unions in Australia, sitting in their offices waiting for the ministers to return. As soon as the division is over, the ministers go back to their offices. When they arrive there, sometimes there will be another division and they have to leave those people again. No-one is going to convince me that there is any sense in that. That is wasting people's time; that is imposing on them. It should not happen. If we do not have the wit or the capacity to determine more effective procedures in this place to make sure that it operates efficiently, perhaps we should not be here.

I have great respect for this place; but I have not always felt this way. When I was a young bloke, I would have willingly turned these places on their heads. But I have developed a respect for them and I know the role that they play. I know that this room is a pressure valve. It is the biggest and the most important pressure valve which exists in this country—across that whole seven million square kilometres. This chamber is that pressure valve. Some people think that honourable members come into a place such as this to remake the world. But they do not. They come into this place to preserve the world and to make sure that, at the same time, they introduce sufficient changes to ensure that society will perpetuate itself.

This is one of the institutions of our liberal democratic framework. In preserving that framework and that structure and modifying it to make sure it is self-perpetuating, this is the most important chamber. All of the work which takes place here and outside of this chamber is to make sure that this chamber operates efficiently.

That is what the honourable member for Bonython and his colleagues applied themselves to. I think it is a great report. There are some elements that I would not necessarily endorse, but we have got to give serious consideration to it. We have to make sure that we utilise the time which is available to us.

Someone referred correctly to the fact that next year we are scheduling 60 sitting days. There are 365 days in a year, 52 weeks in the year and two days in each weekend. So take out 104 days for a start. Then give consideration to the amount of time that we have to spend in our electorate offices meeting with constituents, attending to the functions that we are not legally required to attend—all of those things that we are not required to do. As members of this parliament we are legally required to attend meetings of the parliament in this chamber—full stop. So when people rubbish their members of parliament for not doing what they perhaps think their members should be doing, those people should keep in mind—I say this without any reservations and with no apologies—that the legal requirement for members of parliament is to attend the sittings of parliament in this chamber. Everything else that honourable members do is because they want to service their electorate and their constituents, and they do a good job. That includes those opposite and members on the government side.

One of the reasons that we sometimes have a disrupted question time is that honourable members are generally passionate people with passionate concerns about issues. If they feel frustrated when they are here, I do not suppose it is surprising that sometimes this place erupts. We would need to start examining the passion of our concerns if it were not to do so. In that context we need to examine, as the committee has, the way in which this chamber will do the job expected of it in the most efficient way.

Next year we will sit for 21 weeks of the 52. That means that the House will not be sitting for 31 weeks. Every member of this chamber will have more than enough to do to fill up his or her time in those 31 weeks. Their constituents will see them back in their electorates attending to all of those other things that have to be done. There is a high level of expectation, rightfully so, in the electorate that local members of parliament be visible, involved in issues, accessible and responsive—on some occasions, they will lead their communities in dealing with issues.

I remember being surprised the last time I visited the former Soviet Union before it collapsed and talking about the Supreme Soviet. I asked, `How many times does it meet?'. They said, `It sits two days a year in order to endorse the decisions that have been made by the executive'. There might be a lot that is wrong with this system and there are many people who say it is an expensive system—and it is a very expensive system—but it is a damn sight better than any alternative that we have seen hitherto. There is all the work of committees and of individual members in this chamber. We are all members of political parties. Political parties are fundamental to successful, effective liberal democracies. We have responsibilities to those parties. When we are out developing and promoting policies, raising funds, maintaining contacts, visiting branches, looking after our own branches and looking after our own federal electorate councils, we are doing things that are of fundamental importance to the way in which the parliament operates, and this chamber is of fundamental importance to that central requirement. I congratulate again the honourable member for Bonython, the other seven members of the committee and the three members of the committee staff. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to comment on the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Procedure. I take the opportunity to congratulate the chairman, the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett), and also my own colleague the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan), who was the deputy chairman of that committee, on bringing this report before the House. It is a very important issue and one which should be addressed from time to time. The basis of the report is not about making life on Capital Hill more comfortable for executive government and it is certainly not about making it more comfortable for honourable members. The purpose of parliament, quite clearly, should be to ensure that the wishes of the people are reflected in the legislation which is brought before the House. That legislation needs to be scrutinised, examined, tipped upside down and debated thoroughly before being implemented into law.

PARA.TAB: In the past few years, executive government has taken total control of the legislative processes. Unfortunately, the examination of legislation does not receive the close attention that it did in previous parliaments. That has been to the detriment of the Australian community. The content of legislative changes, naturally, has to be transmitted to the community. Because of advances in technology in the past few years, people are much better informed about the parliamentary processes and debates than they have ever been before.

There are a couple of major problems I wish to comment on, one being the volume of the legislative program. There is the seeming and apparent need of the executive to keep on bringing more and more legislation before the parliament, and this is overwhelming. In fact, Australia is overregulated and overlegislated and there is too much too often when other solutions could be used. One problem is the sheer volume of legislation. The resort to legislative processes by many governments is probably an easy way out rather than trying to solve problems without bringing the legislation into the parliament.

The other problem, drawn to my attention by the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow), is the level of fitness of members of parliament and the range of involvement that they have particularly while the House is sitting. Also, because of the demands they have in their electorates, huge demands are placed on honourable members. I think that the demands have grown as the legislative program has increased. The pressures in running an electorate have mounted at about the same rate. There is an enormous amount to be done both here and in the electorate. For honourable members to maintain their commitment to the processes in this House and to their electorates requires a fairly high level of fitness which we have great difficulty in achieving.

We do all the wrong things. In our eating habits, we sometimes eat too much at the wrong time. Sometimes we eat less and even skip meals. We dart from one meeting to the next, often with a sandwich in our hands. On many occasions we go through a whole day and, when it gets to 11 o'clock or midnight, we realise that we have had only one meal for the day, which was breakfast. I think we have similar problems with our exercise habits. We start with good intentions. I certainly do. I start with the intention of having a swim every day. Sometimes I have a swim but, as the week progresses and I get busier and busier, I miss out on that exercise.

Sometimes we have too many meetings. We have meetings over lunch and over dinner when we have a sandwich. There are times when people should be getting some exercise to try to get their fitness levels up. We all restrict our sleeping time. I run on about four to five hours sleep per night and have been doing so for years. I do not know whether that is good or bad. My colleague Dr John Herron in the Senate says it is bad for us, and it probably is.

The sheer volume of legislation is the starting point of these additional pressures. The executive needs to examine this by going back and looking at whether it is absolutely necessary to have as much legislation or whether there are other mechanisms to achieve the same results.

Question time is vitally important to an opposition and the public because it is the one major opportunity where parliament holds the executive accountable for its actions to the Australian public. I noted with great interest recommendation No. 98, but I want to put another option to the chairman—and I am pleased that the honourable member for Bonython is present. To achieve more accountability in question time, the committee could have recommended a mixture of the practice adopted in the House of Commons with what happens here.

Question time should present honourable members with the ability to give a minister two hours' notice in writing, to give him or her the subject of the question, and the original questioner should be allowed two supplementary questions. The next stage would give a choice to the party concerned of whether the original questioner would ask a further question on that topic, followed by another opportunity for two supplementary questions. If the original questioner declined that option then a further five questions on new subjects could be put to the executive to make it accountable. That would still mean eight questions would be allotted the government and non-government parties. So the committee's original recommendation of 16 questions would fit that framework.

I have seen question time in the House of Commons. I was impressed by the procedure there where a minister is given some notice of a question so that that minister is tested on his or her knowledge of the subject and the portfolio, and a series of supplementary questions are used to derive worthwhile information to better inform the public. Such a question time would represent a mixture of the present practice here and in the House of Commons.

Recommendation No. 115 on page 29 of the report deals with the 90-day rule on questions without notice. The committee recommended that, if a question has been on the Notice Paper longer than 90 days, a letter be written by the Speaker to the minister concerned seeking reasons for the delay in answering the question. That would be like throwing confetti at the Town Hall—it would not have much impact on a minister because he could give a thousand different reasons why he or his department could not answer the question.

I suggest that, if a question on notice is not answered within 90 days, the honourable member should be given a free question in the House. On the next sitting day the honourable member should be able to come into the House and ask that question which the minister has made no attempt to answer. The honourable member should be able to ask a question of that minister and not suffer any penalty in the House because that question would not be included in the 16 questions allotted per day.

The committee has set down 16 as being the mandatory number of questions for question time. I am suggesting that, where a minister does not bother to answer a question on notice, the honourable member would have another opportunity to ask that exact question in the House to get a response from the minister. That would be a severe penalty because it would restrict the number of dorothy dix questions the government could ask. I also noted the dissenting report by my colleagues, for which I commend them.

TALK.START.PARA: —You were going all right till now.

—My colleagues did well—they set out an excellent table for the parliamentary sittings. I am sure the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) would agree with many of these ideas. This table, which appears on page 42, allocates additional time for 90-second statements on both the Monday and the Tuesday. In 1990, I moved from the Victorian parliament to the federal House. The Victorian parliament did not have the facility for 90-second statements by members. A short, sharp 90-second statement is a good way of getting important issues up and running in the House.

PARA.TAB: It is surprising how much can be put in a 90-second statement. In many instances, these statements are the catalyst for further debate. I have heard 90-second statements in the House which have aroused the curiosity of ministers and other honourable members, who have followed up the particular issue, which has resulted in a major debate later. I welcome the timetable set out by my colleagues for 90-second statements on both the Monday and the Tuesday.

I find only one fault with that timetable, namely, the finishing time on a Thursday. A finishing time of 4 p.m. on a Thursday would be more suitable for those honourable members from Western Australia, Far North Queensland and other distant areas. I suggest an earlier finishing time because it would enable honourable members from distant electorates to spend the Friday, Saturday and Sunday in their electorates, to have the opportunity to tell their constituents what has been happening in the federal parliament.

One facet of parliamentary life is representing one's constituents and another is being accountable by telling one's constituents what has been happening, why it happened, the results and what will happen in the succeeding weeks following the debates that have occurred. I do not see any major problem with taking the four hours off the Thursday sitting and adding it to Tuesday and Wednesday. I do not see as too objectionable the House rising at 10 p.m. on the Tuesday and Wednesday. It would mean that the House would have the adjournment debate at 9.30 p.m. and rise at 10 p.m. on the Tuesday and Wednesday of each week. It would not be a late night. It would benefit those honourable members who represent large rural electorates in Western Australia. Those honourable members must be under great pressure in visiting constituents in their distant electorates.

I could have said much more about the debates that occur in this chamber and honourable members reading speeches. In the state parliaments I have seen, very few members read their speeches—on most occasions they are prevented from doing so. As a result, they make a valuable contribution by spontaneously opening up a whole range of issues of which the government has never thought and never considered. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Reid) about the reading of speeches. I share his views. I happened to be in the chamber when a prominent opposition member was reading his speech and referred to government members laughing. I quickly spun around to find out who was laughing and realised that he was referring to me. Then the penny dropped that the comment had been written into the speech. So much for spontaneity. So much for instant humour.

PARA.TAB: I want to spare a thought for the Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Procedure, the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett), who had the arduous task of chairing the deliberations and delivering the final report entitled About time: bills, questions and working hours. He is stoically sitting through the proceedings as we further debate what I think is an excellent report.

One of the criticisms of the report may very well be that the report does not go far enough and that it could have encompassed further changes. However, the committee was very conscious of the fact that previous procedure committee reports have been totally ignored; therefore, it was the view of the chairman and of the committee that we ought to take a limited number of subjects that we were fairly confident of getting through—hence the restriction on the issues raised by the committee.

I confess that when I first came to this place a neighbour of mine, the then honourable member for Prospect, Dick Klugman, was a member of my faction in the parliament. I quickly learned that, no matter how much I might have agreed with Dick's contribution during a faction meeting, it never really did me much good, visibly or publicly, to say it. More is the pity, I think.

But I now find myself in a similar position with the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) who has written to members of the committee saying that the report is a good one and that we should not leave it to the executives of either party but should have a joint debate—not in this place but outside it, because we have much to gain. Unfortunately, I find myself totally agreeing with him.

I think it is rather sad that it will not be the members of the parliament on either side who really make the decision, it is more likely to be the leaders of the respective parties. The agreements they reach about these propositions will be the deciding factor. That is all to be regretted. I would have hoped that there were some decisions about proceedings of parliament that members of parliament themselves perhaps could take without the benefit of guidance from above. But I see that that will not be the case. However, to be fair, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in his response to the report has indicated that there is much about it that attracts him and that he would like to add some things in, which is very good.

I am sure many members of the public would be quite shocked to learn that question time, although it regularly occurs in this place, is not guaranteed in our standing orders. As we are witnessing today, the executive from time to time can decline to have a question time. I am one of those people who feel that we ought to have a question time every time the parliament sits. More importantly, I think one of the biggest contributions the procedure committee has made is to try to entrench question time into standing orders.

There have been many complaints about question time. Anyone who witnesses question time will see what a robust affair it is, with many points of order about longwinded responses and the relevance of some of those responses. Those on the government side could also raise the issue of longwinded questions. But be that as it may, the committee is trying to tackle some of those issues in a sensible way. It felt the best way of ensuring that answers to questions are kept to a minimum and that matters are relevant is by specifying some minimums; that is, question time should at least go for three-quarters of an hour and that there should be at least 16 questions. I hope we will have an opportunity to see that in the next session of parliament.

When framing these recommendations we always have to have a mind's eye on balance and a bit of give and take. I certainly see no harm in extending question time even further. Maybe that would be a bait for the other important innovation about question time: the rostering of ministers. I regret that the opposition rather defensively or alternatively tries to suggest it is a way for executive members of the government, particularly the Prime Minister, to get away from question time. When I first thought about rostering quite some time ago that was my response. But the more I think about it, the more I am convinced it really will give an opportunity to put accountability into the ministerial frontbench. The opportunity to ask question after question of a minister or a group of ministers will only add to accountability. It is quite right for opposition members to get up and say that question time is an important aspect of the government's accountability.

As the honourable member for Bonython demonstrated in his speech, when we analyse the number of questions asked by the leadership groups in the opposition of the leadership groups in the government, we find that they absolutely overwhelm and dominate question time. Rostering will break out of that. Whilst we have opted for a limited form of rostering, I certainly hope that, with experience, we will see a much more widespread form of rostering introduced.

The honourable member for Bendigo also mentioned questions on notice. I have always been a bit disappointed about the amount of time that it takes to get a ministerial reply to a question on notice. The committee again recommends 90 days. The important thing here is that a previous procedure committee nominated that figure. I think that is overly generous in terms of the length of time required to respond. I would certainly like to see a much shorter response time, and I hope in subsequent considerations on this aspect the House might agree to a much shorter response time for questions on notice.

I would also like to talk about estimates. One of the most important changes in this House was the move to a robust committee system. We have to acknowledge the work that the Senate has done in setting up its committee system, and in particular the estimates. The procedure committee has indicated in its report that it would be interested in looking at an estimates procedure and, in particular, combining with the Senate.

If there are members on both sides of the House who wish to affirm the importance of the committee system to this House, then we will have to make some changes. I do not think we in the House of Representatives can argue that we have anywhere near the opportunity to scrutinise the budget that is being brought down. With any power or responsibility people can fail to exercise it; people can trivialise it. So be it. But the point is that we in this House do not have that opportunity. I think it would be a good thing if we were able to combine with the Senate and have joint estimates committees. The Senate may well object to that.

But if we want to reform the committee system, we cannot argue that members and senators cannot work together in committees. We already work together on the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and the Joint Committee on Public Works. We certainly work together in the committee I am pleased to chair—the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues. So there is the precedent—and I think we ought to work very hard at this reform.

A number of members of the opposition have suggested that one way of fixing the procedures of this House is to reduce the amount of legislation. That would be a terrific idea. But honourable members opposite have to understand that the volume of legislation is a reflection of the position of the Senate. It seeks to minimise delegated legislation as much as possible—in other words, minimise the amount of rules and regulation we have in place of legislation. Whilst the Senate takes this particular point of view there will always be a large volume of legislation.

The innovative idea of a second chamber really shows that this House is up with the times. Some might say it shows a bit of productivity improvement. It is not enterprise bargaining because we are yet to get a dollar increase for it—and none is suggested. A second chamber would improve throughput without sacrificing anything. In fact, in addition to providing a second chamber, we now also provide the opportunity of referring certain bills to committees. It will be interesting to see what impact that has on the committee structure.

I certainly welcome the recommendation, but we cannot put off for too long a much closer look at the number of committees we have, to see whether we can amalgamate them with Senate ones and whether we can reduce the number of members serving on them. Giving committees additional workloads—the last additional workload committees were given was receiving annual reports of departments and agencies—has proved to be a very useful tool. But, in referring legislation, ministers will want it to be dealt with effectively and promptly by committees—so the acid will be on them.

I am rather thrilled at having a second opportunity to urge the House to strongly support a change in procedures. We have to take ourselves very seriously if we want members of the public to take us seriously. A failure to address the issues raised in this report on procedure can only lower the esteem that people have of this place. I find it disappointing that the powers of members of parliament are quietly being eroded. I have already introduced a bill to exclude members of parliament from the impact of the Privacy Act so they are able to perform their role as members of this House.

I notice that in taxation legislation the ability of members of parliament to seek information about their constituents and the problems they may be having has been severely curtailed by secrecy provisions. In fact, the ombudsman—both in taxation and other matters—is in an infinitely superior position to ordinary back bench members of parliament who have, I believe, the onerous responsibility of representing their constituents, no matter what. They do not seek a price, and nor should they. They represent without fear or favour. I strongly believe that our powers should not be curtailed. I support the recommendations of the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to be given the opportunity to speak on the report by the Standing Committee on Procedure entitled About time: bills, questions and working hours. I observe—somewhat ironically, I suppose—that the contributions to this debate so far by the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) and others have been uncharacteristically frank and honest. I wish there were more debates of this type in this place. Some of the speeches that I have listened to when following this debate have been amongst the best I have heard. In fact, many of the contributions indicate and underline the point I was going to make, that this report is rather disappointing.

PARA.TAB: In many respects—I cast no aspersions on the chairman, the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett), who is in the chamber—the contributions that have been made about the report indicate how much really needs to be done and how many issues need to be addressed which have not been addressed by the committee. Perhaps I expected too much of a committee that was given a job that was, in my view, a particularly important one. I am prepared to accept that as criticism of the comments I make. Perhaps I am expecting and asking too much. Perhaps being given a little information at this time is better than getting none at all. I certainly accept that that may well be the case.

I am disappointed with a number of aspects of both the majority and minority reports. I hope the remarks I make will be taken as constructive criticism. The terms of reference of the report did not really limit the committee. Yet it has dealt with a number of issues and made some useful suggestions. Nevertheless, it has dealt with a number of important matters rather superficially. In many respects, it has merely treated symptoms of a problem that obviously exist—everyone has agreed with that—rather than actually getting down to what causes those problems or facing up to fundamentals.

The committee's recommendations will do little to allay my concerns that—in many respects and most unfortunately—the House of Representatives has become something of a farce. At least we should say—I could say, anyway—that the Senate, as it is presently constituted, is slightly more relevant. The fact is that nothing is actually decided in this place. Worse still, nothing is ever really debated here—except what I have observed on this occasion. People come and go, and make speeches. They do not even take part in debates. In many cases, speakers from both sides do not listen to what the speaker from the other side has said. So much for debating; unfortunately, that does not occur.

Many people are disappointed when they visit this parliament. The few people who are in the gallery watching the deliberations of the House of Representatives of this country might well be disappointed to find hardly anybody here. School groups quite often come through and they are, for obvious reasons, disappointed. They wonder what members are doing. I heard the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) quite rightly explain that we are doing other things. But my concern is that we have so many other things to do while parliament is sitting. So our attention is not concentrated on what is happening here in this place. We are off attending committee meetings and doing all sorts of other things at the same time. I wonder what people think when they come here.

The fact is that the processes in this place very often are quite irrelevant. Honourable members realise that, I suspect. They do not have to be here too long to realise that what we say in this place does not really make an iota of difference to the end result. Perhaps that is why they stay out of the chamber and do not bother to participate. I wonder whether the people of Australia realise how irrelevant in many respects what happens in this place is. In practice, the government of the day makes the laws. The opposition's role is limited to a bit of behind the scenes pleading and cajoling but, by the time legislation gets into this parliament for debate—whatever that is—it is really all over bar the shouting. That has been of great concern to me.

However, I have come to realise how important the opposition is to the overall scheme of things. I have come to realise, having been a member of the opposition for almost four years, that the opposition in respect of the workings of our democracy is as important—maybe in some respects it is even more important—as the government. Opposition members have a vital role to play. It is very important that we be allowed to play that role completely and fully. It is in the interests of democracy that that should occur.

All the talk in this report about establishing second chambers, main committees and so on will not actually change what the House of Representatives is all about. I was not a member of the committee which brought down this report and I must admit that I have not had a great deal of time to come up with detailed suggestions. But the things that need to be addressed by such a committee ought to be perfectly obvious.

I have alluded to the rights and position of the opposition. I believe the rights of the opposition have to be safeguarded absolutely. I do not know how we go about doing that, but I am quite sure that governments of either political persuasion cannot be trusted with the responsibility of allowing oppositions to work. In my view, convention and tradition—which we rely on at the moment—are not enough. In recent times we have seen the government use its numbers—which it has by virtue of being the government—simply to prevent the opposition from operating effectively. We have endured that over the last few months. I think something needs to be done to ensure that the government of the day cannot prevent the opposition from carrying out its functions to the fullest extent.

I am also concerned about the extent to which we deal with matters purely along party lines in this place. I think that practice should be broken down. It often creates a situation where people are mindlessly disinterested in what is actually occurring in the parliament most of the time. We are all guilty of this. How often do honourable members come in here to vote in a division and the first question they need to ask the person sitting next to them is, `What are we voting on'? We come in here and sit with our party—we sit on the same side as our colleagues—without being aware of what we are casting our votes on. When we do that, I wonder whether we are really representing the best interests of our constituents.

Obviously, party affiliations are important; they will always be important. Allegiances will always be important. But, ultimately, we are here to represent our electorates and our constituents. If we are not following what is happening in this place and making intelligent decisions about casting our votes, I do not believe we are doing our jobs properly. Yet the present system encourages us to take that mindless approach to the proceedings here.

Private members business is covered in the report. This has to be a joke. As kindly as one may view this government's practice of devoting time to private members business, there is no doubt in my mind that, whilst this provides a genuine opportunity for members to raise matters of concern to them and their electorates, the truth is that we know—but I do not know whether the people of Australia do—that nothing ever happens. We can come in here and support, often on a bipartisan basis, an important motion. We can debate a matter which is important and, in the end, the time expires and no decisions are taken. That may be one way of getting things off our chests or getting up and making speeches about something important, but often things are introduced, debated and never decided.

There have been many such issues, but one comes to mind particularly. The previous member for Macquarie moved a motion dealing with the funding of abortions through Medicare. Without canvassing that issue, it was apparent that there was a considerable amount of bipartisan support for that motion which would have prevented such funding. I do not know whether the parliament would have voted for or against that motion in the end, but the point was that the government of the day obstructed and prevented any efforts to have a vote taken on that motion. That sort of occurrence is quite common. Ultimately, it makes a joke of private members business, which is controlled by party and government considerations. Governments of either persuasion have not, and will not, allow voting on private members bills.

A lot has been said about question time. The report deals only superficially with the symptoms; its puts bandaids on the problems. It talks about rostering and all sorts of other issues. Whilst they may be part of a solution to the problem, that is not the real issue. The point is that the Speaker must be in control of question time, and there is a very clear case for some sort of independent Speaker. I would not want to cast aspersions on you or your colleagues, Mr Deputy Speaker, or indeed on the Speaker, but the point is that when the Speaker is from the government party, even with the best of intentions, no-one would even pretend that he could do his job entirely adequately.

If we cannot have some sort of independent Speaker, the clerk might be best placed of all to sit in that chair. But it should be somebody who could actually chair the proceedings and make sure that questions were asked and answered in accordance with the standing orders. They never are now. We have talked about this matter. The standing orders say that questions should be relevant. That is not a difficult requirement to meet. If one looks up the dictionary, one will find that the meaning of `relevant' is quite specific. Yet, day after day, that standing order is not complied with. We need to have someone in the chair who will require answers to be in accordance with the standing orders. That must occur.

Dorothy dixers should clearly not be allowed. In some respects, government members probably should not be able to ask questions at all, unless they are serious and genuine about asking about matters which are of concern to them or their electorates. That must have been the original intention of question time. Yet, day after day, we see government members standing up here and asking dorothy dixers which give ministers the opportunity to make statements—which they ought to do at some other time—or simply criticise the opposition.

Some of the dumbest dorothy dixers are the ones which begin `Has the Minister heard about a report in the newspaper about the Leader of the Opposition saying such and such'. The whole process is fundamentally flawed. I would have thought those sorts of issues could have been addressed in the report. Ministers should make statements. They are enabled to do so by the standing orders. That is what they ought to do rather than use question time to make statements.

If the roles were reversed, this same criticism would apply to the opposition. It has been said that the opposition spends too much time devising tactics simply to score political points at question time or entrap ministers, rather than giving members on either side the opportunity to ask questions about matters which concern them or their constituents.

The behaviour of members during question time is deplorable. I think children should not be allowed in the parliament during question time, let alone be encouraged to come to see question time. They go away with a terrible impression of what goes on in this place. I do not have time to go into the reasons for this behaviour—other members have alluded to them—but the fact is that members of this place behave very badly.

There has been a lot of talk about sitting hours. Once again, the committee has done a bit of work on that subject. But, in the end, it has not addressed some of the real issues. Something has to be achieved by the parliament. If this place is to be merely a rubber stamp for the government we might as well come here and get the job done as quickly as possible. I am quite happy to sit here for 24 hours a day. If we do not achieve anything, we might as well go about the process of government in the completely perfunctory way in which we go about it now. Why pretend, by changing all the sitting hours around, that we actually do something here when the present system militates against that completely?

I do not see any particular merit in finishing early. Unless it counts, we might as well get it over with and get home to our families. I personally do not worry too much about being tired; it is a feature of this job, as it is of other jobs. If one has been in the services, the police force or whatever, it is not too much of a problem. In any case, the facilities in Parliament House are excellent for those members who want to look after themselves and stay fit. I ask the committee: what do we do if we finish here at 8.00 or 6.30 p.m.? Are we to go out and socialise? Most of us will continue working anyway. I am in favour of getting on with the job.

I would like to make a lot of other comments, but I am going to run out of time. I do not think meetings and committee hearings should be going on while the parliament is sitting. I think once again that underlines the fact that members of parliament are not really concerned about what is happening in the parliament and are not concerned about taking part or being informed about the matters that they are voting on.

The report accepts all the existing antiquated concepts and practices. It talks about bills being read three times. In the end, I am not sure whether that means very much to anybody. A lot of time is wasted in attending divisions. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I am pleased to be making a contribution to this debate on the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Procedure. Although I am a new member in this place, I have been involved with politics for some 30 years. I share with previous speakers alarm at the low esteem in which political life is held in Australia. It is little wonder that the casual observer of Australian television is appalled by the way in which parliament is reported. In turn, and without blaming the media, it is a fair reflection of what goes on in this House, especially at question time.

PARA.TAB: A few weeks ago, on a committee inquiry in the south-western and western suburbs of Sydney, the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles), the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) and I met a group of students and had lunch with them. When those students discovered that we were from the Liberal Party, the Labor Party and the National Party respectively, one of them asked, `But don't you fight each other all the time?'. I was saddened by that. It touched me very deeply to think that this young person, who was in a special school because of his tendency towards violence, saw in the politicians of Australia a role model for violence. It was also particularly ironic because we were attending there as part of our inquiry into violence in schools. Here we were assessing these young people and reporting back to the House on ways of removing violence from schools, when we, the inquirers, were seen to be models of violence.

I compliment the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett) for his work on the committee and in the preparation of the report. One of the report's key areas is question time. While I would like to see question time brushed up and polished a little, I would not like to see it gutted. As the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) suggested, it should not be held so late in the afternoon that it becomes irrelevant to the evening news media. If we are to have a lively, no-holds-barred—albeit more decorous—question time, it should not be held at such a time that no-one will be interested in it.

I would also like to see the introduction of a time limit at question time because that might justify having supplementary questions. I suggest a time limit of four minutes for answers to definitive questions, with perhaps two minutes for answers to supplementary questions. That would change the practice of the opposition leadership always questioning the government leadership.

Another approach—I hope the honourable member for Bonython will take this on board—is for question time to be held in two parts. I think it was the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) who suggested that question time could be a little longer. If it were of an hour's length, the first half hour could be devoted to the leadership asking and answering questions on national issues, while the second half hour could be devoted to ordinary members' questions on matters of relevance to their electorates and areas of expertise.

I remember listening to the proceedings of parliament in the days of Menzies, McEwen and Whitlam when those sorts of questions were asked. They were answered honestly and intelligently. There was also an overriding proviso that, if a question were vague or esoteric, the minister had the right to place the question on notice. That is fair enough. If an honourable member asked a question about some remote corner of his or her electorate, of which a minister had little or no knowledge, he or she would have to expect that question to be put on notice.

I am sure that many backbenchers on both sides of the House would regard being able to ask those sorts of questions preferable to the present situation where coalition members are deprived of the right to ask questions or else have questions framed for them, while government backbenchers have to dish up dorothy dixers. Dividing question time into two half hours to deal with different types of questions gives the leadership a fair run and allows backbenchers on both sides of the House to ask questions on matters of relevance to their electorates and areas of expertise. That might lead to more rational debate.

As regards committees, I would like to see House of Representatives committees with some of the powers of Senate committees to examine legislation and to examine not just those matters that arise from reports and annual reports but more broadly based matters—matters, say, of policy development, policy accountability and functional accountability. I have not been associated with the House long enough to be able to suggest a mechanism for that but, broadly speaking, I would like to see the committees of the House made more relevant to particular portfolios—some of them already are but many of them are not—and with wider investigative powers.

The honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns) touched on the subject of members business in his contribution to this debate last week. I doubt that a 90-second statement is long enough for a good point to be properly developed. Towards the end of those statements, everyone is rushing like a Bondi tram to finish, rather than concentrating on making a sensible and meaningful point. My recommendation to the House—again, I hope the honourable member for Bonython will take this on board—would be for the time to be increased to 2 1/2 minutes. One could develop a point and make some impact in 2 1/2 minutes, whereas 90 seconds is just too short. In the 15 minutes available, it would be better to have six speeches, each of 2 1/2 minutes duration, than bashing through 90-second statements which end up sounding more like gobbledegook than measured consideration of particular issues.

Other speakers have raised the issue of relevance in relation to question time, but relevance also impacts on other areas of business. It appears to me that standing orders 145 and 321 have lost some of their relevance. When I first came to this place eight or nine months ago, ministers were tabling documents on request. Nowadays, documents are seldom tabled because everyone appears to be hiding behind House of Representatives Practice page 559, where it provides that a minister can claim immunity on the basis of the privacy or confidentiality of a document. At times that is clearly nonsensical.

If I remember rightly, on one occasion in the sports rorts affair there was a letter to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) from the Benalla Shire Council that the minister would not table. Even under the Queensland local government act—I imagine it would be the same in Victoria—that document would be freely available to any ratepayer in Benalla who wanted to look at it. After all, it was a letter from one instrument of government, local government, to another instrument of government, federal government. How could it possibly be either private or confidential? We need to look at the relevance of questions, the claiming of privilege with documents that arise in questions and, in particular, whether we could have a better format than that currently existing in House of Representatives Practice on page 559.

On the matter of the sitting hours, I would like to put forward a proposition that falls between the recommendation of the committee of the honourable member for Bonython and what we are doing at present. Although I share broadly the view of those honourable members who have suggested that we should not be driving people's health into the ground by sitting until 11, 12, 1, 2, and 3 o'clock in the morning or sitting on a regular basis until 11 p.m., I suggest that there are dangers in sitting to 8 o'clock three nights a week and 6.30 on the fourth night. I think honourable members will find that after 8 o'clock on the first three nights one of two things will happen. I am not reflecting on my fellow members, but I think there will be a tendency for fairly long dinner parties that go on into the evening, which will be no more healthy than the present practice of getting up at 11 o'clock. On the other hand, we will end up having endless committee meetings, caucus meetings, joint party meetings and the like. We will possibly find that, far from getting home at 8 o'clock, we will end up still sitting until 10.30 or 11 o'clock doing some form of parliamentary business, probably committee and caucus work. I suggest that will not evoke any great improvement.

Finishing at 6.30 on Thursday night will mean that some members will certainly be able to get home. I suppose that will mean that there will be this great rush from 5.30 onwards for people to get away early—there will be unofficial deals with the whips and so on—and for the proceedings on Thursday to start to peter out from about 4 or 5 o'clock in the afternoon. Those members who go to conferences around Australia find that, on the last day of a conference, especially one that finishes at midday, nothing much happens after morning tea on the last day of the conference. I suspect that that is what could happen on Thursday evenings.

My suggestion is that we have two early nights and two late nights. When many of us have come from fairly remote areas of Australia and we have made the effort to get to Canberra, we are not going to be unduly stressed by sitting until, say, 10 o'clock on the first two nights. I am pleased that the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) is here because he might share a view on this. I suggest to the Leader of the House and the honourable member for Bonython that on the Mondays and Tuesdays the House rise at 6 p.m. for a dinner break, sit again at 7.30 until 9.30—that is, have two hours of good debate—and have the adjournment debate at 9.30 with members going home at 10 o'clock. It is not an excessively late night, but it would allow members time in the evening to give some consideration to their duties here in the House.

I agree with the concept that on the Wednesday and Thursday nights the House could rise early. I would like to see the Thursday night go on until 8 o'clock, but I suppose 6.30 is fair enough if people from South Australia and Western Australia have to get away. I think that my suggestion would also have another effect. It would be a great pity if there were never a time when members could meet over dinner during a session. Other than when we do our committee work, there is very little opportunity for any camaraderie between the government and the opposition. (Time expired)
